movie_review_blurb: Slick and solid in moments, Den Of Thieves disappoints with its reliance on easy plotting and gruff, overcooked acting. One for Butler completists only.
If you're ever considered whether a port-a-potty would make a good catapult, this is for you.
By-the-numbers comedy with only the occasional giggle to recommend it.
For the first time in a while, it looks like Disney's cracked the formula without needing to rely on Pixar to figure out the equations.
Hopkins does his thing, and Hallestrom leaves him alone to do it well.
Wells knows how to extract the goods from a great cast, but it's in service of a somewhat mundane story.
Not up there with the Farrelly brothers' classics, but still a worthwhile, farcical comedy.
As a violent but mediocre nod to '70s action thrillers, it's a curiously inert affair, leaving the one-time Rock to pass the time by shooting people in the head. Missable.
A solid thriller with McConaughey doing what he does best.
The clichés come thick and fast in this ponderous thriller.
Brand fan? You'll likely enjoy his antics. But Russellophobics would be better off seeking out the original.
Not knowing enough for the Glee/Easy A generation and laden with enough Prom-movie clichés to have older viewing running for the exits, it's old hat.
A Twilight pastiche with all the wit you'd expect from the makers of Scary Movie and Meet The Spartans.
Sweet-natured, undemanding family fun.
anyone who has seen the trailer has seen a good 80% of anything worth watching here
it perfectly sums up the muddled feeling of a gothic horror romance that never feels all that romantic nor particularly scary.
There have been far, far worse remakes out there. Harmless, feel-good fun.
It's not quite in Balboa's weight class, but Real Steel at least has some heft.
While it doesn't spoil the legacy of John Carpenter's film, it doesn't exactly add much to it either.
Contagion's not the feel-good movie of the year, but it's effective, compelling and smart and will have you twitching at every cough you hear for days afterwards.
For all its flaws, this remains worth some of your hard-earned time.
This is one property you'd do well to stay away from.
There are a lot of laughs lurking within the shiny 3D wrapping and snow-covered silliness.
While the Devil might have a claim to hold all the best tunes, on the evidence of this, he really needs a word with his film development department.
A joyous blend of heroism and humour that raises the stakes even as it maintains a firm grip on what makes the individual heroes tick.
we get a standard story, some decent setpieces and only a few funny lines...Take the ride, but don't blame us if you end up saddle sore.
It's occasionally entertaining to have these characters back in our lives, but for the most part this fails to party like it's 1999.
Brash and bombastic this new entry might be, but it's also criminally boring.
An object lesson in how not to adapt a comic book. A crushing disappointment.
Borrowed liberally from stock British elements (Dougray Scott's character is restoring a boat! There's a chase to stop a lover leaving!), there's nothing new to enjoy here.
It may only deserve a C for achievement, but it ranks a B+ for effort.
Driven along by a decent cast who really turn it on during the musical moments, letting their steps tell the story.

A mix of savoury issues and sweet songs that lets the latter win out. It's short on the subversive vibe of John Waters' version, but if catchy tunes and a cast having a blast are all you're after, this will leave a smile.

Often mainlining its message at the expense of laughs, this is unassuming fare that just about holds the line between floating and sinking. Carell's a solid centre, but someone needs to tell him he's better than this.

Ken Kwapis' comedy ploughs a well-tended furrow, from the hard truths our lovebirds discover to Williams' family-friendly schtick. There aren't enough laughs or sparks to warrant saying, "I do!" at the box office.
Like its leading men, War's got a few handy moves up its sleeve, but when the dust-ups clear it emerges underwritten and over-cranked.
Follow US audiences' lead - pitch your cinematic tent elsewhere.
Unsatisfying, hokey and never that scary (unless you're the type who jumps at every loud noise or sudden appearance in this sort of movie), The Unborn outstays even its brief lifespan.
Race proves a fun, snappy update to a goofy kiddie cult film.
There's a lurking feeling that somewhere along the production line, nervous studio types ordered changes to make the movie more commercial.
Skewers the action genre while also finding room for sheer madness.
Rises above expectations, even though it never quite shatters the genre mould.
Murphy goes through the motions and no-one will be surprised at the outcome, but the journey is what matters in these movies and Imagine That makes it bearable for anyone over the age of 10.
Edited with the finesse of a toddler on a sherbet dib-dab rush, the film dashes from one over-stylised battle sequence to the next.
It's a divisive and sometimes difficult film, but if you let it into your heart, you'll end up grateful.
It might not be the most original tale, but it's visceral, visual and vitriolic, with a line in sharp, dark humour.
It's exactly the sort of film that the title would suggest, but it's also disarmingly fresh and very funny.

Lithe, bold, often funny and full of characters to cheer for, it never pretends to be anything more than a trigger-happy romp. If that's what you're after, The Losers offers plenty of explosive entertainment.
DreamWorks could be entering a period of fresh creativity. With How To Train Your Dragon and a balanced, darker-hued and very funny Shrek finale, they've found the magic again.
DreamWorks could be entering a period of fresh creativity. With How To Train Your Dragon and a balanced, darker-hued and very funny Shrek finale, they've found the magic again.
Smith might be the focus, but while he's got the charisma and the moves, it's Chan who makes it punch above its weight. Nice scenery too.
Even the hardest of hearts will have melted by the time the lights come back up.
Dazzling, energetic, sharp and endlessly engaging.

The insane comedy/action hybrid emerges as a nutty, funny, unashamedly weird action comedy hybrid that is more consistently laugh-grabbing than many of its contemporaries doing far better business at the box office.
More certain of its tone than Tyler Perry's melodramatic rom-coms, it's a good-hearted comedy of modern manners that provides a chuckle or two.
In what might prove to be one of the most egregious examples of concept far outstripping execution, The Darkest Hour ends up as this year's Skyline: aliens+paper-thin screenplay=cinematic snooze.
A perfectly workmanlike sci-fi action thriller... but there are so many little nods to the original that anyone with a passing awareness of it is reminded all too often of its memorable moments.
Despite the odd rip-roaring tune and some sturdy performances, this yuletide tale is as memorable as last year's sprouts.
A rote run-and-scream wannabe scarefest that fails to deliver more than rudimentary chills.
This is Anderson still finding his feet, but the steps and swagger are confident.
The film opens on a huge battle in the Greek city of Argos, but it often ends up feeling like the director bought it cheap at the high street namesake.
Once danger presents itself and the screaming starts, it all becomes a basic space horror film that plucks tropes from the peg and rarely does anything interesting with them.
Despite boasting a seemingly ripe filmmaker working with proven actors, the result feels more like a bigger budgeted yet disappointing episode of The Outer Limits.
Confident, assured, muscular and moving in places.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A Dame To Kill For shares some of the downsides of the first, particularly dubious female characterisation. But this retains the gritty, grueling vice-grip on graphic-novel noir that made Sin City so enjoyable.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The movie's title character may find her brainpower increasing as the running time counts down; chances are you'll feel like your own IQ levels are dropping just as rapidly as you watch it.
The critters themselves are part-Jawa, part-Gremlin creations and provide much-needed fun in a tale that's perhaps lighter than previous Laika efforts but still has plenty to offer.
Does deliver some fun undead action, yet the laughs are never as big as you'd hope.
This second helping isn't quite as fully cooked, but it's a fun sequel that dares do a few different things.
movie_title: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Though not every element of the grander mystery story works, there's plenty here to keep you thinking.
If you're after something decidedly unusual The Book Of Life is well worth checking out.

Elba gives good psycho smoulder and Henson occasionally gets to flex her acting muscles and break out of the damsel-in-distress clichés when she's fighting back against this conflicted home invader, yet neither can overcome the script's limitations.
The truly effective emotional arc is handed to the furry member of the cast.
A joyless and pointless remake.
Cheap and cheerless, Norm's appeal melts faster than the polar ice.
Quick on its wits and fast with its fists, this is Black firmly back doing what he does best. And nobody out there does it better.
Fitfully funny but failing to really build to much of anything, The Boss is mostly a bust. Even its main character would have a hard time buying it.
This is Mel Gibson back to doing what he once did best, just older and grumpier. The movie has problems but delivers when it needs to.
Less sleepless, more insomnia cure. For all its attempts at action, it's a rote, dull crime thriller with little fresh to offer.
By driving back to the core homespun wisdom of Cars, the third film is a course correct from the second. But this is still not vintage Pixar.
Silly and aimed squarely at the younger crowd, Captain Underpants has enough spirit to be entertaining. Just don't expect it to work all the time.
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: When a film can waste a character actor as respected as Fichtner, you know there are bigger problems beyond a slightly hackneyed script.
What pours from the screen while you watch this comic book adaptation is seething, unadulterated cynicism.
Feels like someone copied a schoolmate's work and added a lot of their own occasionally enlightening but largely unnecessary scribbles.
Cleese's cracking script gives it a solid foundation, but it's the supporting cast who make this movie wanda-ful.
The mooted Stooges - Sean Penn, Jim Carrey, Benicio del Toro - dodged a bullet judging by this muddle of creaky slapstick and laugh-free plotting.
Like a street shyster looking to make a score with a shell game, the director keeps trying to play with your expectations. Unfortunately, you're likely to end up feeling ripped off.
movie_title: House at the End of the Street (2012)

movie_review_blurb: More than ever, forgoes real attempts at character and story for lots of repetitive zombie skirmishes.
Some sparkle and plenty of motion.
With a script by that manages to dilute Adam Sandler's baser instincts with a real love for Universal monsters, Hotel Transylvania is no Grown Ups-style torture.
A sprightly, slightly twisted take on the romcom genre.
The Man With The Iron Fists definitely isn't the most polished first effort. But if you approach it as a sloppy, OTT martial arts outing, you'll find the fun.
movie_title: The Man With the Iron Fists (2012)

movie_review_blurb: This second chapter might not add much that's new to the mythology, but it's scarily entertaining enough to stand alongside the first.
An impressive and brave attempt to tackle a book many thought could not be adapted.
Warm, witty, wacky and wonderful, Wreck-It Ralph deserves to stand alongside the best of Disney, while also feeling like it wouldn't be out of place at Pixar's table.
Has a lot to offer if you like your fantasy big, brash and jovial, but with a hint of horror in places.
It's not often we're given something that looks so dazzling, features such an impressive, eclectic cast, and which will leave your noggin buzzing with ideas.
The sharp ends in Smashed are here for all to see, and Ponsoldt never shies away from their spiky, thought-provoking effect. Yet he also finds grace and warmth in the story.
Gonzo freakiness in such doses that cult status is practically ensured.

An ingenious blend of hand-drawn animation and live action, spliced with humour that's by turns madcap, surreal and violent, Roger Rabbit demonstrates that it's possible to push the technical boundaries while still cooking up decent characters and plots.
Clever premise, witless execution.
A worthy addition to the Pixar class of classics.
Huge scale entertainment with guts and a heart - even if the brain is sometimes lacking during the more human moments.
A gratuitous spruik for the money-churning web giants but not without moments of wit. The duo rediscover a little of their old magic.
The pace was a guaranteed adrenalin-pumper, Dennis Hopper was suitably psycho, and Keanu and Sandra made their careers.
The pottery scene is still sexy despite numerous spoofs.
Occasionally charming but mostly bland fare from Weitz, despite the reliable cast. About A Boy remains the best showcase of his talents.
A stylistic departure from the shaky aesthetic of the first film. Sadly, most of its nervy shocks and creeping sense of unease go the same way.
While not the balls-out action movie the marketing suggests, this Rock-powered family drama is not without its moments.
Shawshank aside, this is the best non-horror Stephen King adaptation of the bunch.
The film is so talky, repetitious, visually stuttery, and slackly paced that sitting through it once is like seeing it twice.
This is the most frustrating film. It's probably no fault of the makers, but it's rare to have to assess a documentary for what it doesn't have.
movie_title: It Was Fifty Years Ago Today... Sgt Pepper and Beyond (2017)

movie_review_blurb: If it's about or based on The Beatles, the question is always the same: how on earth can anything new be said? In the case of Ron Howard's Eight Days a Week: The Touring Years, surprisingly quite a lot, is the answer.
movie_title: The Beatles: Eight Days a Week - The Touring Years (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A 'slightly' more grown up take on the bumbling spy premise that will keep the little audiences entertained and the older guardians subdued.
A missed chance. There's a good foundation to build on, but the immediate film is let down by a lacklustre story and god-awful script.
The closing 30 minutes sag a little, but overall this is storytelling at its most engrossing.
At times overcomplicated with needless plot additives, but with no previous filmmaking experience Dugain has produced a taut and thoroughly enjoyable historical drama.
Relive some of your own dreadful family vacation moments with National Lampoon's comedy classic, Vacation.
Quite simply one of the best sports movies ever.
One of Hollywood's best underdog stories.
A definite must-see that's perfect for a guys' night out or a relaxing date.
It's safe to say computer graphics will never be the same.
Any list of classic guy movies would be incomplete without an appearance from Brian De Palma's Scarface.
Even with Angelina Jolie thrown in for forensic sex appeal, this dog won't hunt.
This version has action, yes, but the love triangle among Arthur, Guinevere and Lancelot is diluted, and there's nothing exuberant about a dutiful slog through the muck.
The second of a planned trilogy about class divisions, The Inheritance seems to say that money ruins everything. Save yours for another movie.
The Prince is a wet rag, the slapstick stepsisters are dull and even the fretful Sam seems colorless.
I, Robot is fun, even when it relies a bit too much on standard police-procedure cliches.
The story is tired, the comedy forced and the mother's larger-than-life quirks are an acquired taste.
Dispels myths about the 'gangsta' aura that clings to rap and shows this poetry of the streets in all its different forms: social protest, entertainment and aggression.

It breathes life into a small story that has larger ramifications. It also shows that America, as represented by Jackson Heights, is still the promised land for people about whom movies are rarely made.
A movie needs more than a few sexual innuendos and throaty purrs to keep us from taking a catnap.
Features strong performances from Colin Farrell as bi-guy Bobby, Robin Wright Penn as hetero Clare and Dallas Roberts as gay Jonathan.
movie_title: A Home at the End of the World (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The movie is mostly a series of frenetic clashes, dubious near misses and car chases. It lacks the human interest and snowy splendor of the first movie.
Some culture-specific humor that doesn't translate well and a protagonist who is downright silly--- always chuckling and cackling to himself in a way that gets on the nerves.
Its shapelessness and the cultural differences in acting style will keep this version filed under 'cult oddity.'
Mark Achbar, Jennifer Abbott and Joel Bakan have crafted an informative, amusing and unnerving overview of the history and consequences of corporations.

It offers something rare in the bond between Andrew and Sam. Their connection follows a believable arc from their first awkward encounter to a specific, believable intimacy, without which the movie's jokiness could have rung hollow.
This foolishly conceived movie version of the 1960s sci-fi TV show is not only achingly dull, it has no respect for its origins.
This has all the ingredients for a top-notch thriller except one -- a thrill.
A screechy chick-flick relationship comedy with a lot of things working for and against it -- mostly against it.
Kentis keeps it simple and direct, and the effect is devastating.
It's bliss, I tell you!
If you want to see how other couples fight, We Don't Live Here Anymore is as good a place as any to visit. But why, exactly, would you want to?
This is a wickedly funny skewering of a prewar London society gone mad with frivolity.
A welcome departure from typical movies about teens.
A thorough, gutsy and appropriately scuzzy-looking documentary by Michael Gramaglia and Jim Fields, featuring rare footage and interviews with the stars of the CBGB era.
movie_title: End of the Century: The Story of the Ramones (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Features even more toddlers acting in a way only collectors of velvet paintings will consider irresistible.
A knockout.
It's a colorful collage with a few choice tidbits amid run-of-the-mill kibble.

In movie heaven, the original is still the one for all time. Still, this update is remarkable for its performances, resolve and timeliness, and could well revive the snoozing political-thriller genre.
The joke isn't fresh, but it holds up well in this crackling remake of George Romero's 1978 sequel to Night of the Living Dead.
Spider-Man 2 is a perfect blend of summer action, a big movie with a deeply personal story.
There is nothing more to the movie than the usual thrills.
Brilliant and infuriating, wise and naïve, outrageous yet unforgettable.
I'd like to believe I could watch Cedric the Entertainer all day long. The tedious comedy Johnson Family Vacation puts a strain on that theory.
This funny, surprising gem joins the ranks of Risky Business and Say Anything.
Alamo buffs will be delighted, and everyone else will be treated to something that feels like Old Hollywood crossed with new sensibilities.
A time waster.
A dulling experience that can safely be admired from afar without it ever engaging the senses.
Tom Jane is a great-looking Punisher, darkly handsome and chiseled, even if the movie goes nowhere with the character.
The whole enterprise is scrubbed clean of the very quirks such a comedy craves.
Among the many skills required by a documentary maker is the ability to make reticent people blossom. Michael Almereyda has done that in This So-Called Disaster.
Just when you think there is nothing left to mine in the body-switch genre, 13 Going on 30 is an unexpected pleasure, a buoyant comedy that will make you feel young again.
More chemistry between the leads would have helped.
A mean-spirited black comedy saturated with dog-poo jokes and only intermittent yowls of mirth.
Haneke's work is always unsettling, from Funny Games to The Piano Teacher. Here, he shakes up a familiar genre so that catastrophe feels imminent even after the screen goes dark.
Carefully designed for maximum blandness.
This whiny, unpleasant comedy of infidelity makes a good case for staying celibate with the phone unplugged.
The information here isn't necessarily new, but it is packaged in an acid-tongued way along with powerhouse visuals that drive home the filmmaker's nakedly political views.
Delivers more fun than there is slime in a green ogre's swamp.
Nearly unwatchable.
A thoughtful, beautifully acted story about feeling alive before it's too late to feel anything.
An entrancing experience for Potter fans.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Despite a few goofily entertaining moments that are so over the top they are instant camp, the movie suggests that the hero's name derives from 'ridiculous.'
Bland as old kitty chow and unappealing to the eye.
An amusing and slightly alarming documentary about Scrabble nuts.
A funny, tender, satisfying blend of fiction and cinema vérité.
The makers of Seducing Doctor Lewis have a cute idea, but they milk it for all they can, sometimes to the point of embarrassment.
Feels disingenuous and dogmatic.

Old monster movies were thrilling in a way that mingled terror, sexuality and a real preference for the monsters over their tormentors. Van Helsing is a kiddie adventure on an endless, meaningless loop.
Although special effects and careful editing pitch in, the wild-kingdom authenticity on display is an astonishing achievement.
It's such a pleasure being in the company of these actors as they work with character-rich material that if they burst into the audience and swindled us out of our wallets, we would gladly oblige.
An implausible story that enfolds kinky sex with nationalistic fervor.
Gives a fascinating and alarming taste of how a 1974 kidnapping that now seems quaint has morphed into the monstrous terrorist tactic it is today.
movie_title: Guerrilla: The Taking of Patty Hearst (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Director Vikram Jayanti makes a nail-biter out of the historic 1997 match between the charismatic, mordantly funny Kasparov and the steamer trunks of circuitry.
movie_title: Game Over: Kasparov and the Machine (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The most gorgeous movie of the year.
How many movies recapture the blithe spirit of Frank Sinatra and his Rat Pack, plus a sense of old-school star glamour?
Touching and saddening.
A movie that approaches the level of great boxing films, like Raging Bull, by using sport as a metaphor for human nature.
Unfortunately, though it may finally gain an Oscar for director Martin Scorsese, it is not his best work. The movie is disappointingly flat.
Hirsch is dead-on with his weary deadpan in the face of high school torment, sexual confusion and parental absurdity.
Based on a true story, the movie has abundant humor and uplift -- but it's a heartbreaker of extraordinary dimension.
movie_title: The Sea Inside (Mar Adentro) (The Sea Within) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Meet the Fockers, a sluggish sequel to the anarchic domestic comedy Meet the Parents, is one visit too many.
An amusing and unusually compassionate look at today's corporate culture.
A queasy comedy in which Pacino burns a hole in the screen while the frivolity around him sputters.
movie_title: William Shakespeare's The Merchant of Venice (2004)

movie_review_blurb: This movie reeks.
A slight movie and a major downer.
Generic and uncomplicated, which doesn't mean it doesn't work. Tears will well up on cue with the precision of the best orchestra.
Hawke and Fishburne make it work, supported by a mostly strong cast.
Alnoy's unnerving mood piece is spare and atmospheric, even funny.
As documentaries go, Watermarks is nothing special. But the women who inhabit it are sensational.

Another of those real-estate horror movies that sticks it to urbanites who overspend on picturesque Victorian houses in towns where the locals resent them. For city folk in rambling country homes, something wicked this way comes.
Writer-director Khyentse Norbu sees paradise not as the seat of perfection, but as the warmth of a simple, loving community.
A stately pace and gradual intro suck you into the rhythms of this parallel universe, one in which desperate children live alongside grownups and yet remain invisible.
It's strictly amateur hour.
There's no refuge in this uncomfortably realistic movie, and that is its strength.
Has some wan jokes, incongruous slapstick and the occasional embarrassment, which may keep it from being as popular as the Newberry Award-winning novel by Kate DiCamillo.
The clumsy humor doesn't translate well.
movie_title: Up and Down (Horem Pádem) (Loop the Loop) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: It's a slight story to begin with, and the movie teeters on camp with its jokey filler material.

Elektra is stripped of the unrepentant ferocity that made her a crossover hit in the first place. Here, she quickly succumbs to her gooey, maternal side -- which means if ever there's a sequel, she'll have no edge.
A marvelous cross between Secretary and Lost in Translation.
Gloriously feverish ode to what drives us to do things great and terrible.
Nicolas Cage usually brims with personality, but you wouldn't know it from this pedestrian ripoff of Raiders of the Lost Ark.
As a love story, Wimbledon is a washout. As a meditation on sports psychology, it might help improve your game.
[Mac] gives surprising wisdom and heart -- along with the laughs -- to what could have been just another generic baseball comedy.
A droll gem that celebrates movie love with feeling and deadpan humor.
The movie's great joke never wears out its welcome: Many of the living are virtually indistinguishable from the undead.
The movie's engine is the relationships and the characters' inner lives, all of it boiling with emotional intensity.
There's no affection in this mean-spirited sendup of 'the business' and nothing to mitigate its sour taste.
A sobering documentary done in a whimsical style.
It has the wooden, self-conscious veneer of a vanity production.
The movie purports to be a comic meditation on metaphysics, but it has no intellectual resonance and resembles nothing so much as a sendup of psychotherapy.
It's a riveting high-wire act by a young man on the verge.
Not since the students spilled out onto the streets in Fame has musical performance been so infectious a part of coming of age.
Vera Drake is perfect down to the last detail.
Even with the whimsically understated Irons as the oblivious husband and that lion Michael Gambon as the ghost of Julia's acting teacher, director István Szabó's movie leaves no impression.
The film is remarkable for its depiction of the everyday life and chores of a vanishing culture, and for making its points with clarity and precision.
The Final Cut can't cope with its own weirdness.
Caustic fun.

The good news: Real-life porn star Siffredi turns out to be a terrific actor. Who knew? The bad news: The scene with the garden implement. The scene with the red cocktail. The scene with ... I can't go on.
Not since Scrooge got a look at Christmas future have the holidays seemed so shudderingly depressing.
The audience will be small for Stella Street, a daft mockumentary based on a BBC-TV skit about celebrities who converge on suburbia.

Farmingville doggedly taps into the larger forces at work, including government disregard of an escalating problem, and offers only the smallest glimmer of hope that the two sides can work things out through ingenuity and compromise.

Movie love is usually so idealized it ennobles behavior that ordinarily would be considered stalking. Enduring Love deliberately smudges the line between what is bizarre and what is simply human nature.
A gore movie with no teeth.
Everything works in this movie.
This fictional 'what if' scenario is a bit campy and stagey, like a session of Opera 101.
The combination of old-time Hollywood valor and ahead-of-its-time surprises makes this restoration a big event.
As a study of the creative process, Finding Neverland is too literal, yet gives a healthy idea of the richness and ingenuity of Barrie's work.

It's not The Incredibles, or one of those animated features that spent zillions on character design, pedigree and verisimilitude. But SpongeBob is a sweet, silly thing with a child-friendly esthetic all its own.
Languorous art movie.
It's a bit of an oddball story, but surely there was a less plodding way to elaborate on it.
Visually glorious.
The movie is a compendium of tortures that would horrify the regulars at an S&M club.
Dysfunction seeps from every pore of this family, and the anger and ugliness of the characters overwhelm not just the story but the movie's stunning National Geographic location.
A beautifully composed tone poem about unspoken group dynamics in an isolated community.
Big, bloated and only intermittently amusing.
This extraordinary film refracts truth through the prism of memory, until what you get is a tragedy of Shakespearean dimensions, full of sacrifice and betrayal.
Pleasantly cheesy but undistinguished martial-arts and horror fare.

An enchanting animated feature.
Without Diesel, there's not much gas, at least not from the nonvehicular elements.
It's a humiliating comedown for Ford, and he looks creaky and grumpy, obviously aware that he is miscast and dreading every scene.
An elegant period drama of passion and betrayal.
Wan humor, no spark.
As its own collection of Angels' Greatest Hits, Full Throttle winds up embracing the spirit of the original TV series, supplanting it and gleefully eviscerating it.

While the plot and action are all deliberately familiar, director Gore Verbinski steers a continual course for sheer, mindless, rope-swinging, crow's-nest-hollering summer fun.

movie_review_blurb: Despite a plethora of 'naughty bits,' it's a yawn.
A sweet, lovely, if perhaps overlong movie.

movie_review_blurb: A substantial improvement over X-Men, in many ways.

Groundbreaking, yes, but not as important as it should have been.
Rank amateurs toiling away at their 'craft' could be interesting if they tried to be more like Russ Meyer and less like pornographers.
Portrays not only the fear that Israelis live with every day, but also the difficulties in a nation where people are arriving from all over the world, not knowing Hebrew.
Quote not available.
The conclusion is surprising and quite exciting, as this self-contained little southern world unravels.
I chuckled just once through this 105 minute affair, and that just doesn't cut it.
The real star here is some excellent computer-generated effects that actually look real.
Robert Redford, in a surprise acting tour de force, really stretches his style and mannerisms to become Henry Brubaker.
Quote not available.
I do believe President Bush was actually directing this movie. It has all the hallmarks of his idea of history, pretending that enemies are villainous evildoers.
Reminds me of a Christopher Guest movie, but perhaps not quite so ribald and witty.
The only thing that has improved with the remake is the quality of the blood.
Quote not available.
It is a carefully plotted film that leads to an extraordinary ironic climax.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
A brilliantly constructed, touching but unsentimental look at the last days of East Germany.
Not a great film because filmmaker Robert Flaherty does not seem to understand fiction.
This movie has dated considerably and can best be called a cold war relic. Still, I did find it intriguing and an interesting premise.
Not long enough to be a 'message movie', but insightful enough to hold our attention while exploring the lives of these characters.
Seems cheaply shot and perhaps that is why it just does not ring true.
movie_title: Ça commence aujourd'hui (It All Starts Today) (1999)

movie_review_blurb: I have reservations about the filmmakers' theories and I find it hard to believe that these men would want to be characterized this way.
The problem with films like this is that it easy to pander to the sexual, show the act, without thinking about the drama that could be unfolding.
A Hollywood big screen version would have cut out too many details, so the miniseries format is ideal in letting this piece of history unfold.
The problem with Nick Broomfield's documentaries is, well, Nick Broomfield.
Vehicle 19 rivals Running Scared as the best of Walker's smaller, grittier (read: home entertainment) titles.
Melancholy and funny, quirky and touching, it stands among their strongest work.
Female empowerment and gorgeous vistas from Ridley Scott,

Blue Jasmine is a handsomely shot (sometimes luminous, sometimes airily naturalistic), structurally deft (flip-flopping between the SF present and the NY past) and terrifically performed (expect Oscar noms) dramedy.
A smart, cosmopolitan, thoroughly modern whodunit comprised of geometric visuals and pulsating sexual violence.
movie_title: L'uccello dalle piume di cristallo (The Bird With the Crystal Plumage) (1970)

movie_review_blurb: An absorbing thriller that favours vivid characters, profound ideas and Old Testament morals over propulsive plotting and set-pieces. With lots of blood.
Seductively lensed, sparely scripted and superbly performed, this does away with Gothic nonsense to offer a modern take on the undead myth.
What sounds like a hangover of The Hangover is actually pretty money.
The Python team's surreal take on the legend of Camelot bursts with inspired lunacy.
movie_title: Monty Python and the Holy Grail (1975)

movie_review_blurb: One of the more solid '70s horror remakes, but it lacks the verve and potency, romance and heartache of the original. Still, the haircuts are a vast improvement...
More funny than scary, it often feels like Deep Blue Sea meets The Mist... but what's wrong with that?
The quips about life, love and art are ageless.
Occasionally potent but mostly risible, this tale of the occult sees Rob Zombie cast a weak spell. Disappointing.
Far from being a cold, scientific study from a filmmaker frequently accused of placing a pane of glass between his work and his viewers, this sensitive film emerges heartfelt and humane.
Trailer trash Hitchcock spliced with overboiled film noir.
[Crash's] remit? To teach talented but undisciplined pitcher Ebby (Tim Robbins) about hurling a ball. And a little about life.

This sublime picture is directed by Robert Bresson, who painstakingly crafts his signature visuals -- stark, forceful and rigorous in their attention to detail -- to bring a striking luminosity to the bleak events.
movie_title: Diary of a Country Priest (Journal d'un curé de campagne) (1954)

movie_review_blurb: Of course, it's annoying. But it's also funny, touching and true, striking chords without ever reducing Raymond to a performing puppy. Definitely.
The scuzz-chic visuals, sleaze-synth score and deep-cutting gore are effective, and shooting from the killer's POV proves a valid USP.
The Paperboy is a throwback to the exploitation cinema of its period. As such, it's grungy, tasteless and hard to take your eyes off.
A disappointing entry to the sci-fi / action-movie canon.
The Dracula make-up is a homage to Max Schreck's Count Orlock, but Werner Herzog's 1979 effort owes little else to FW Murnau's silent classic.
movie_title: Nosferatu: Phantom der Nacht (Nosferatu the Vampyre) (1979)

movie_review_blurb: Mia Farrow excels as the pretty young thing who suspects she's carrying the spawn of Satan, but it's Polanski who emerges as the real star.
Craven knows which big, red Freudian buttons to push, turning Freddy into a true monster from the Id.
A masterpiece of animation and imagination.
A gross-out slapsticker to rival The Evil Dead.
The quality of the filmmaking is irreproachable; swathes of originality outweigh the odd recourse to cliché; and the merit of the storytelling at times matches the film's colossal ambition.

Pioneer features underwater sequences so breathless they'll thrill even James Cameron (director Erik Skjoldbjærg made the original Insomnia) but Petter's truth-chasing is at times too frantic and melodramatic.
A handsome thriller, absorbing for its duration and with a couple of neat rug-pulls.
Willow Creek's terror tactics are all about what you don't see, while the source of the chills is kept ambiguous: over-active imagination, pissed-off locals or honest-to-God beastie?
Don Siegel's taut, bleak, noir-flavoured picture is arguably the science-fiction B-movie of the 1950s, an age when screens glowed with the atomic threat and undulated with scuttling, supersized bugs.
The filmmaking is exemplary, the veracity palpable, as Rosi paints a complex portrait of Sicilian society.
Washington undoubtedly has the game - he's mesmerising here, however much the movie slides out from under him - but the material has a long way to go to be his equal.
Doesn't have the heft of Zodiac or the verve of Se7en but Gone Girl is a masterful adaptation and a superior crime-thriller.
A socio-political satire that thrums with warmth and spontaneity, yet so enraged Communist authorities it was banned.
Young, far-from-dumb and full of comeuppances.
Other areas of innovation and influence are often overstated, but its silent scream still registers.
movie_title: The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari (Das Cabinet des Dr. Caligari) (1920)

movie_review_blurb: More sure-footed than Expendables 1 and 2, and considerably more pumped up - it pauses for neither breath nor a change of colostomy bag. Dumb fun.
Among the blood, sweat and (ahem) salty tears are musings on desire, family and emasculation, but this is Kim at his most mischievous, the laughs drowning all.
Well-made and well-acted, Wakolda is let down by rampant contrivances and on-the-nose metaphors.
Welcome To New York will madden many but delight the Big Apple auteur's admirers.
It's an American tragedy indebted to Russian literature, alive with detail and ritual and embedding viewers in the souls of men, the heart of a community and the spilled guts of a nation.
Pfister should be applauded for making a non-franchise property with ideas and aspirations but Transcendence is nowhere near as grand as its title. Gleaming visuals aside, it's a disappointment.
By the beard of Zeus! Brett Ratner delivers fast, fun thrills to score a sound victory over Renny Harlin's laborious The Legend Of Hercules.
Jersey Boys is a solid watch that seeks to deepen the emotion of the jukebox musical.
Wonderful.
Bigger and better - 22 Jump Street joins the exclusive list of sequels that out-gun their originals. We're already knocking at the door of no.23...

There's imagination, spectacle and thrills to spare. There's a freshness here too that comes not only from the structure, but from Edge Of Tomorrow being a shiny new property in this cyclical age of sequels, prequels and spin-offs
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It's theatrical but increasingly fascinating as an arrogant director (Mathieu Amalric) auditions an actress (Emmanuelle Seigner) for a stage version of the titular novel about sexual submission.

Between this and his work for David Cronenberg, Pattinson is suggesting his career post-Twilight will sparkle like Edward Cullen's skin. Michod, meanwhile, confirms he's a filmmaker of considerable talents.
Leigh makes no judgements on his protagonist but instead chooses to place before us a man both ordinary and extraordinary as he shuffles about his daily business.
Frustratingly superficial and speckled with cod-psychology and unintentional humour.
A triumph-of-the-underdog documentary so amusing and inspirational you'll have to Google events to ensure it's not a mockumentary. Back of the net.
Favouring vitality over originality, this needless remake of District 13 comes with fleet-footed sequences but plenty of stumbles, and strains far too hard to be 'cool'.
Fassbender's faceless performance offers a masterclass in body language, and that wide-eyed, open-mouthed mask invites band members, and viewers, to project their own readings.
A cunning, suspenseful thriller that bears comparison to the Coen brothers' Blood Simple, Blue Ruin is an impossible-to-ignore calling card from writer/director Jeremy Saulnier. Hollywood awaits.
Superb.
FBI agent Clarice Starling (Jodie Foster), brainiac cannibal Hannibal Lecter (Anthony Hopkins) and tackle-tucking serial killer Jame Gumb (Ted Levine) make for one of cinema's great ménages à trois.

The Freaks And Geeks boys prove that weedy action men are where it's at. Pineapple Express sometimes zones out but mostly blows minds and inspires some delirious giggles. Like the titular grass, really.
The action and anxiety are believable, the violence sudden and the performances - especially those of Sheridan Smith as an East End Sarah Connor and Jack O'Connell as a thug-come-good - are strong.
A fresh angle on a mini-classic. It's about '80s football violence, yes, but it's also about today's gang culture. And friendship and family. Nick Love shoots... and scores.
A comedy-drama full of beauty and ugliness, profundity and profanity. Eventually loses its way but, for at least 100 minutes, it's some sort of masterpiece.
This thoroughly pretentious offering is more childish and terrible than enfant terrible. The most startling - and boring - film you'll see this year.
Sugar is a human story told with immense skill, right down to the deft transitions and the soft fuzz of the electronic score.
Gaudy, ghoulish, this particular creepshow plugs into the EC Comics of the '50s, laughing uproariously in the face of death. Forgettable, but groovy while it lasts.
A Prophet is a compelling, forceful drama.
Mother is competent, no more, no less.

Bright Star does nothing new (if it wasn't based of fact, it would be accused of adhering too closely to formula) but it does it very well, displaying real craft and benefiting from terrific performances.
The biggest surprise of all - it's actually pretty average, at least by Lee's own impeccable standards.

Forcefully acted and sumptuously shot in gleaming black and white, it is an artistic picture that occasionally - nay, frequently - strains too hard for credibility, as Coppola's script shoots for nothing less than tragedy.

Some of it hits home, raw and emotional. Other sequences (a karaoke scene, moony shots of Nanjing) thrum with a tender melancholy. Most of it, though, is boring, nonsensical and off-puttingly convinced of its own worth.
movie_title: Spring Fever (Chun feng chen zui de ye wan) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Up, as ever, is all about the characters. And the observations of human (and animal) behaviour. And the exquisitely timed physical comedy.
Still scary, violent and very, very funny.

Arthouse? Grindhouse? The Passion Of Joan Of Arc: Unrated Edition? Defying all boundaries, Martyrs relentlessly dishes the visceral pain and emerges as a work of not just ceaseless terror but also gravity and beauty.

Life, death and a love that burns bright and brief as a firefly... Only Fincher could lighten up and still turn in a film obsessed with transience, with mortality. Flecked with flaws, Button nonetheless stands as a monument to its maker's talent.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Directed with pace and a little too much surface gloss by Mabrouk El Mechri, JCVD works less as a suspense thriller and more as a treatise on celebrity, a confessional for its star.
Virtuoso. A film of pin-sharp principles, cross-hair precision and suffocating tension, this Coens stunner hits like a cattle gun between the eyes.

The sound of silence... Indulging in few words and even fewer edits, Carlos Reygadas lets his luminous images do the talking as he ponders the human condition and more. Some viewers will cry with boredom; true believers will shed tears of pain and joy.

Southland Tales finally emerges as an admirably bold dud. Trying to sum up EVERYTHING that's wrong in the world in one kaleidoscopic go, it's messy, misshapen and curiously muffled. Seems the world does end with a whimper after all.

The teen support cast are vacuous and director DJ Caruso strays a little too far into Grand Guignol territory for the over-extended climax, but Disturbia's otherwise bang on the money: $80m at the US box-office was no fluke.
Lucid and forceful, Zodiac is sensational in the right way.
Mischievous and magical, Gondry's bizarro movie offers visual pearl after visual pearl but no string to tie them together. Où est Kaufman?
Relentlessly grim but in a phony, Hollywood kinda way.
[Director Kris Isacsson] tries to bring a little enterprise to the inevitable scenes of bickering and moody silence, but by now the vitalising tactics seem out of place.
A soggy effort.
Wilde Salomé is passionate and absorbing, though the insertion of lengthy clips from the film might irk viewers who've just watched it.

He runs, he stumbles... Jason's newest beginning is satisfyingly sick but far too slick, Nispel jettisoning grubby, home-movie visuals - and with them all tension - in favour of really lustrous leaves. Disappointing.
Haneke demands full attention as a patriarchal community crumbles to the ground and the seeds of fascism are sown. A masterpiece.
Lovely Bones is a touching, at times distressing film. It deals with loss, grief, rage, familial breakdown and love, most of all love. But it's also energetic and entertaining.
Paranormal Activity trafficks in shadows and shivers yet is more malevolent than a dozen Hostels.
Crammed with detailed craft, its appeal is further widened by dealing in universal fears: homesickness, identity, mental health.
Jaws is a perfect blend of set-pieces and story, its formula so hard to capture it's now near-mythical - filmmakers have been chasing it like Ahab chasing Moby Dick ever since.
Underdogs, dreams, imagination, artistry, unashamed emotion... it's the cinematic equivalent of a big red hug.
A super-entertaining, super-slick love/hate letter to horror with a final 20 minutes that's stunningly bonkers.
Playing like a mumblecore The Graduate set in the affected milieu of the Tribeca art crowd, Tiny Furniture announces Dunham as a talent to watch...
Good enough to survive evoking Bicycle Thieves and The 400 Blows, this small story contains universal truths, told with irresistible force.
Don't expect glamorous outlaws, sunny locales and exotic masterplans - this low-key thriller lifts the rusted lid off an all-too-real world of despairing criminality.

A traditional ghost story set very much in the here and now, The Innkeepers proves that the Spanish and the Japanese don't have a monopoly on the sub-genre while confirming writer/director Ti West as one of the major talents in horror today.
A handsome, ambitious period drama full of modern-day parallels.
Changed ending aside, Fincher's take is as faithful as it is fearless. And Mara rocks.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Rod Lurie's remake transposes the action from cloudy Cornwall to sticky Mississippi but keeps the meat of the story intact, along with the violence.
Star-crossed lovers Wormald and Julianne Hough can't match Bacon and Lori Singer, but over-30s will tap feet and the Glee crowd will mime along.
McKee's oblique storytelling and Sean Spillane's mournful music add unusual textures to an otherwise savage attack on patriarchy.
Using superimposition and double-exposure to bring the rickety wagon and its wretched occupants to ghostly life, The Phantom Carriage balances visual poetry with emotional violence.
An action crime movie that's as cerebral and surreal as it is red-blooded.
Almodóvar joins PT Anderson, Aronofsky, von Trier and Scorsese as the latest big-name director to dip a toe into horror. There won't be blood, but the head wounds are vicious.
British horror has rarely hit these heights since the mid-'70s.
Mother's Day holds effective sequences, ramming home its (recycled) message: the animal lurks in us all.
Twenty minutes in, you'll begin to feel like you're in detention.
Super 8 doesn't possess the top-to-bottom greatness of the films it's modelled on but, in shooting for the stars, leaves 90% of modern blockbusters in the gutter.
It's gross but will it gross? Burton and Depp's cannibal musical is an especially acquired taste - Oliver! reimagined by Eli Roth. Brave, brutal... ballads?
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The most toxic, rapturous, melodramatic, operatic movie about a mentally disintegrating ballerina you'll see all year... And featuring some of the best dance sequences ever.
More camp than corrosive, A Serbian Film is hard to take seriously.
While The Town glories in genre tropes it also dumps any overt stylings or clipped, staccato dialogue, instead keeping the action alive and lithe. Keeping it real.

Like Paranormal Activity and Let The Right One In, Ti West's shocker favours old-school tropes - plot, character, suggestion and suspense - over gorno extravagance. Seems like the Devil has great taste in films too.

Fans of Zombieland, Dead Snow and the 28... Later films will likely wonder why the Don of the Dead doesn't stick to stroking his cat. Old-school horrorheads, meanwhile, will find enough here to rejoice that George is still playing with dead things.
Isolation, desolation and the odd skirmish: this is Hillcoat's apocalypse, not Hollywood's, but it lacks McCarthy's power.
Sam Raimi's visceral debut remains a benchmark of modern horror.
A romantic-comedy to die for... It's dead funny... etc., etc. DeHaan and Plaza ace it in a sure-footed zombie movie more interested in heart than braaaaains.
Kim Jee-woon's riff on the western is an entertaining frolic back-loaded with gore and guffaws. Arnie's back!
Wiig and Hader give winning, finely nuanced turns in a film that deftly mixes light and dark.

There's a thin line between visionary and hodgepodge, and it's a line that King Arthur crosses and re-crosses with an abandon that rivals Hunnam's accent sliding from Cockney to Californian and back again.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This is a downbeat character study that scratches at Brooklyn's underbelly.
A very big, exceedingly dumb thrill ride. Live your life a movie at a time; for 136 minutes, you'll be free.
Less geared to adults than Pixar movies, but enough fun to prevent toys being thrown out of prams.
Directors Jeremy Gillespie and Steven Kostanski are ones to watch.
The prolific auteur was a huge admirer of Douglas Sirk, and there are echoes here of All That Heaven Allows, but the intensity is all Fassbinder.
movie_title: Angst Essen Seele auf (Ali: Fear Eats the Soul) (1974)

movie_review_blurb: Set in a smart home but sincerely dumb, its only hope is that people buy tickets expecting a clown.
The violence is cyclical, no one learns anything, and any points gained for absurdism are lost by landing too many punches square on the nose.
Kelly Reichardt's discerning, awards-laden drama plays things quiet but is one to shout about.
Shot for $5,000, this '70s black-and-white curio was the "trainer wheels" for Waters' shockfest Pink Flamingos.
It's a spiritual film, tracking Robert De Niro's 'Nam vet as he takes the wrong path towards cleaning New York's streets, minds and souls.
Strikingly original, brilliantly acted, this serio-comic masterpiece constantly swerves expectations.
[The Meyerowitz Stories] sees writer/director Noah Baumbach return to his favourite milieu of family misfortunes, though this time with the humour and warmth a little higher in the mix.
Most alluring are the crumbling neon cityscapes, real world/cyberspace fusion and the musings on identity.
Could have been a grand folly but instead it's just grand. Will make audiences break into grins like its characters break into song.
If ever there was a film that epitomised the saying 'no pain, no gain', this is it. Packs a real wallop.
Knock a star off if you're feeling cynical, but otherwise surrender to this fun, funny, spirited debut.
Once watched, it's hard to forget.
Watch Adam McKay's flash and funny financial crisis movie The Big Short and then turn to The Measure of a Man to see the human cost.
movie_title: The Measure of a Man (La loi du marché) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Party on, dudes! With tracks from Blondie, Van Halen, Sugar Hill Gang, The Cars and more, Linklater's frat-pack com is an absolute blast. Prepare to be amazed and amused.
Dusting itself off from a nightmare production, this western finally arrives to shoot, for the most part, straight and true. It certainly ain't no calamity Jane.
A shallow, slow-burn horror that takes an age to get to the strong meat but looks good doing it.
Robustly performed but full of second-hand plotting and tedious slo-mo.
Informed, balanced and deeply humane.
Zak Hilditch's breathless... thriller tears through orgies, mass suicides and murderous rampages to conclude on a scene as moving and terrifying as the climax of Melancholia.

This is Malick turning graceful, ever-decreasing circles, though there's a thrill to seeing him traverse hotel rooms and studio lots, nightclubs and strip clubs, after a career wrapped up in the period and pastoral.
Davis' debut is a touch over-stretched but impossible to resist - a classy crowd-pleaser with an especially magical first half.
Uneven, but plenty of fun.
French acting royalty including Juliette Binoche gamely play up, but the theatrics are an acquired taste.
A low-budget relationship drama with high aspirations. Makes for a self-assured and pleasingly down-to-earth debut from one-to-watch Michell.
Switch off that television and head out to the cinema: Gyllenhaal is sensational headlining a pitch-black satire with its finger on the pulse.
An exploitation movie that, paradoxically, exhibits too much good taste. Still, expect "Saws all!" to become a 2018 catchphrase.
The spectacle is decent and the relationship dynamics absorb just enough to fill the lengthy run time.
No small achievement. Alexander Payne re-confirms his position as one of US cinema's premier filmmakers.
McDormand is an unstoppable force in a fiercely intelligent, profanely poetic movie that shifts tonal gears at breakneck speed.
This last (?) encore feels a little tired, but fans will still feel the urge to raise their lighters/glowing phones.
An excellent middle chapter bursting with wit, wisdom, emotion, shocks, old-fashioned derring-do, state-of-the-art tech, and stonking set-pieces.
A Christmas horror-comedy - and one of the best since Gremlins.
Chbosky traces a rote story arc but works hard to avoid mawkishness, while Julia Roberts and Owen Wilson dial down their star power to serve the story as Auggie's fretful folks.
The unflinching filmmaker behind Funny Games, Hidden and Amour returns to his decidedly uncuddly pet themes.
Face crumpled, eyes darting, Jones captures the wounded humanity at the core of this psychological thriller.
Poverty and poetry, delinquency and deluxe wonder... this child's-eye view of lives on a knife-edge is terrific.
Shooting in 65mm, Branagh delivers all of the eye-saucering exteriors you'd expect, as mountaintops soar, sunlight glints at the end of tunnels and stations snuggle under a duvet of blue snow.
The Shining buzzes madness and malevolence from every frame.
Well-acted, well-made and well-intentioned, but not quite strong enough to gain the awards traction it would desire.
With less to say for itself and the tics and tropes of the spy genre already upended, this sequel at times runs around and around in circles, even if it often looks golden whilst doing it.
The tension only serves a tale of obsession and sacrifice - qualities easily lost against the wondrous effects and heart-swelling hope.
movie_title: Close Encounters Of The Third Kind: 40th Anniversary Release (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A royal treat.
Aronofsky's seventh movie, mother!, is being marketed as a 'psychological thriller' but reveals itself to be his most out-and-out, not to mention outré, horror movie yet.
The real reason IT works is because it takes time with the kids, revelling in their colourful lingo and comradeship as much as their fears.
Neil Marshall's Dog Soldiers did much the same thing with far more wit, energy and innovation.
The doc-flavoured approach lends both urgency and tedium, while the blend of miniatures, stop-motion and CGI references the various looks of his 63-year history.
Expect Bigelow's deep-cutting drama to be part of the conversation come awards season.
Tommy's Honour scores a hole in one with its unpacking of the class wars at play.
Much mellowing and life-learning ensues in a plodding dramedy, though the glint in MacLaine's eyes makes it almost worth your while. Almost.
No Badlands, but the best of the recent minor Malicks. And it features Val Kilmer with a chainsaw.
Holland, like his character, is clearly having a blast throughout, and you'll know just how he feels.
With Streep on grandstanding form and Grant given a rare chance to show his range, this is an intelligent dramedy that moves and amuses.

Sliding between past and present, Almodóvar drip-feeds revelations to hook viewers while crafting an affecting study of lost, grief and guilt. And the actresses, as ever in a Pedro joint, are terrific.
The plotting is tangled, the emotional undertow slight, but the action keeps on coming, including a blistering multi-player sword fight on speeding bikes.
Handsomely shot but rather inert.
This is a movie that never lets up or allows viewers to do anything but meet it with fearsome focus. Much like its subject.
The Martian is a savvy blend of the technical and the personal, of outer and inner journeys, and of teamwork and isolated glory.
The Visit is a genuinely creepy and chucklesome horror-comedy with a touching (if somewhat over-sentimentalised) core.
It's flawed, yes - Frances is frustratingly underwritten, her psychological fault lines spoken of but never shown - but it's also swaggeringly cinematic. And it has Tom Hardy vs Tom Hardy...
Mission: Impossible - Rogue Nation might have its hi-tech gadgets, but it's a pleasingly old-fashioned affair.
Fittingly for a movie set inside someone's head, Pixar's 15th feature is a fireworks display of fizzing ideas and bursts of imagination.
Not up there with key US influences Annie Hall, When Harry Met Sally and Jerry Maguire, but a romcom Brits can be proud of. Make a date of it.
Hits all the routine beats but is plenty entertaining, with Pacino rediscovering his enviable pizazz to headline a quality ensemble.
It's rare indeed to find a modern horror film more interested in characters than plot or body count, and the naturalistic storytelling pays dividends.
In the battle of the 2015 behemoths, the maxed-out madness of Mad Max: Fury Road sets an extraordinarily high bar - then pole-vaults clean over it and smashes the entire rig to smithereens.
Jarrold struggles to sweep things along with quite enough vigour - budget constraints crowd the edge of the frame - but Gadon is intoxicating as Elizabeth. A star is born.

Watch Big Game with a straight face and it's ridiculous; view it as tongue-in-cheek (and Rare Exports proved that Helander has a wicked sense of humour) and, if not sublime, it's certainly entertaining.
Fun enough, but not the lightning-bolt-to-the-heart update we hoped for.
Ambiguity is The Falling's currency, and it's all the richer for it.
So fast, furious, ginormous, crazed, maxed-out and heart-on-sleeve emotional is this gloriously ludicrous instalment that it's impossible to see where an eighth could go.
Over-long, but a work of great artistry and emotion. As the woodcutter says upon finding our heroine: "A gift from heaven".
movie_title: The Tale of the Princess Kaguya (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Misses the energy and vitality of Gregg Araki's best work, but there's more going on here than immediately meets the eye.
Who let the dogs out? This is Homeward Bound: The Incredibly Harrowing Journey ...
It's no Heat but the niggles are easily forgiven given the virtuosity on show and the mood oozing from every frame. No one shoots faces, architecture and gunfights like Mann.
Never sure if it wants to be a hard-edged character drama or pacy action-thriller, Son Of A Gun has plenty to admire between the tonal wobbles.
Wahlberg finds his most interesting role since The Departed in a film that's heavy on atmosphere and suspense but shy of a full deck when it comes to characterisation.
Family entertainment with death, limb-lopping and other horrors. If you go Into The Woods today, you'll be surprised how faithful this is to the dark stage musical.
Frenetic, splenetic and dizzyingly inventive.
Scott, aided by CGI though many sets were constructed, has conjured a vision to make Cecil B. DeMille quake.
A sombre, '70s-flavoured crime drama with strong, interior performances from Hardy, Gandolfini and Rapace. Feel the (slow)burn.
The opening is a hoot and the closer would make George A. Romero quake, but much in between is as flat as Cusack's battery.
Of the six tales on offer, four are excellent and one decent - a high strike rate for a compilation.
This, undoubtedly, is the movie that fans wanted, the movie that fans deserve.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: This is high-altitude satire that dares to press hot buttons while targeting and empathising with all, black and white.
Those who can spot a Fulci reference will likely embrace this creepy, bloody haunted house movie more than mainstream viewers. But if you like your horror, it's a treat.
Scorsese blends his twin religions of Catholicism and cinema to considerable effect.
Isabella Rossellini's singer Dorothy is a heart-rending open wound, Dennis Hopper's Frank Booth one of cinema's great nutjobs, and Lynch's control a thing of nightmarish beauty.
This biopic coulda been a contender if superior specimens like Rocky and Raging Bull hadn't landed their punches first.
A mesmeric treat of a film - one of Jarmusch's best.
Think Luis Buñuel spliced with Hieronymus Bosch.
movie_title: We Are the Flesh (Tenemos la carne) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This first instalment showcases just enough of them to make you sign up for the full expedition.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Not without glitches but an energetic study of one woman's refusal to settle for anything less than her share of the American Dream.
Will infuriate those who like their movies tight and tidy but go along for the ride and this is wind-in-your-hair thrilling. A modern classic.
Writer/director Babak Anvari blends war, patriarchal rule, folklore, spooky kids and one of the best jump scares since Carrie's hand burst from the grave, into a startling debut.
Not quite magnificent but certainly Fuqua's best since Training Day and a rare remake that actually delivers. Yee-haw!
Consistently funny, frequently hilarious. Just don't order one of those jumbo hotdogs before you take your seat - never mind the guilt, you'll choke laughing.
More flyaway entertainment than vintage Woody but a joy while it lasts. Allen, at 80, has a spring in his step.
Nathalie's brought to life by Huppert's subtly complex turn and Hansen-Løve's fluid, unfussy direction.
A mildly compelling thriller with a solid cast.
The 80-year-old director still has plenty of fire in his belly. Warm, belligerent and, in places, unbearably moving.
The Violators suffers from inevitable comparisons to Andrea Arnold's Fish Tank, but is anchored by McQueen's terrific performance in her feature debut.
A superior entertainment that marks Tarantino's most mature outing since Jackie Brown.
It engages but falls a good deal short of Ex Machina's fierce intelligence... [However,] the performances are robust.
A rigorously detailed telling of an important story that never loses sight of the human devastation.
Hail, Caesar! is a love letter inked in arsenic, at once celebrating the artistry of Hollywood and cringing at the crass commercialism and rampant phoniness of it all.
Robert Eggers' measured, meticulous debut builds into one of the most genuinely scary horror movies of recent years.
Charlie Kaufman shows us what it is to be human. Plus the best use of Cyndi Lauper's 'Girls Just Want To Have Fun' in the movies.
If you like bleak 'n' brutal thrillers like The French Connection, Se7en and Animal Kingdom (who doesn't?), this is the movie for you.
Supernaturalism for sceptics: teaming up for the fourth time, Nichols and Shannon deliver another slow-burn, grounded triumph.

Goldblum's Levinson sums it up while talking about the mothership sucking up whole cities from the Earth's surface: "What goes up, must come down." Sadly, he might have been talking about the franchise.
A beguiling, potent tale that will make snapperwhippers of even the most surly adults, it is, in a big word favoured by its even bigger-hearted hero, scrumdiddlyumptious.
Starts off flavourful, turns rather bland. This Injustice League jaunt proves that DC is still a long way behind Marvel for on-screen action.
Cloverfield was all about making viewers to gasp and pant; 10 Cloverfield Lane demands you hold your breath. As unnerving as it is surprising.

This sensitive portrait builds towards an uplifting conclusion, where, despite his tremendous setback, Collins is seen moving ever forward - albeit less sure-footed than before - and with definite purpose.
Pulp's final show of their 2012 reunion tour is given an unorthodox spin in this documentary from New Zealand film-maker Florian Habicht.
movie_title: Pulp: a Film About Life, Death & Supermarkets (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The sheer class of the production ensures that it's not entirely ruined by its flaws.
This documentary about one day in the life of Nick Cave brilliantly encapsulates what makes the writer/musician tick, and does so in bravura style.
A spirit of youthful naivety does permeate the tale, but while it's sure to charm some, others may find it all insufferably twee.

There's a distinct lack of archive footage of the band in their prime, but the director makes a good stab at bringing to life the studio sessions that produced such treasures as The Ballad of El Goodo.
movie_title: Big Star: Nothing Can Hurt Me (2013)

movie_review_blurb: It's the scenes detailing Tom's efforts to bring all the material together that demonstrate what he's really capable of, and they give the film a satisfying pay-off.
Hewis's film captures the inconsequential nature of nine-to-five desk jockeying, while the Bristol backdrop lends it plenty of character.
This isn't the confessional exposé some would hope, but it is a reverent profile of a fascinating, funny and inspirational gentleman.
Sure it's grimy, gimmicky and over all too quickly, but Fernanda Urrejola's titular killer babe - an impossibly sexy, semi-clad, bullet-spraying fury - is a creation assured cult-icon status.
movie_title: Bring Me the Head of the Machine Gun Woman (Tráiganme la cabeza de la mujer metralleta) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A female warrior attempts to leave her killing days behind in this polished but overblown Chinese period swordplay adventure.
Like its heroine, the story never dwells on the heartbreak, delivering plenty of wry smiles and surprises as the four adults are forced to confront all the glaring problems in their marriages.
Poignant and charming, this romance will strike a chord with anyone who has loved and lost, and its optimistic message lingers fondly in the memory.
[A] breezy romp that offers Jackie Chan one of his more memorable recent roles.
movie_title: Little Big Soldier (Da bing xiao jiang) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Refreshingly free of those redemptive clichés that blight biopics of less controversial figures.
A blockbuster that makes up for in mood and spectacle what it lacks in dramatic bite.
Swayze is given little to work with as the bewildered dad, while Tim Curry's shameless turn as a Royal Mountie with an inexplicable Scot's accent is sheer panto excess.
A film every bit as imaginative, colourful and cleverly constructed as their plastic inspiration.
Mossy Bottom Farm's mischief-maker bounds effortlessly onto the big screen in this fun-packed yarn from Aardman.
Skilfully assembled and comprehensive in its research, this is a must-see for comic fans and essential viewing for Dredd-heads.
While the seemingly endless procession of obscure bands does get a bit wearisome, it does at least mean this isn't the Kurt Cobain-skewed, cash-in feature you might expect.
[An] efficient thriller that's sure to tick all the boxes for fans of Asian action movies.
With a doomed romance subplot adding emotional resonance, this is extreme Asian cinema with substance, style and soul.
This ambitious reboot of the Godzilla franchise from Toho Studios is a curious beast, but its unconventional nature makes it stand out from the rest of the monster pack.
Just like the Sleafords themselves, Christine Franz's film is unpretentious and unfiltered, and it brilliantly captures the momentum and excitement of a band as they make their breakthrough.

Splits, suicides, a brainwashing cult and industrial quantities of hairspray and make-up all play their part in the story, with the fragile Yoshiki fulfilling the role of tortured artist to perfection.
Niall McCann's documentary celebrates the legacy of the fiercely independent record label Chemikal Underground.
The fact that those people come out in their droves to pay homage speaks volumes.
The familiar approach doesn't spoil what proves to be an infectiously entertaining epitaph that was well worth the wait.

The close-quarters fight choreography is convincingly realistic and captured deftly on camera, but this lacks the cheer-on appeal of Uwais's breakthrough movie The Raid and too often feels like an exercise in overkill.
Mark Craig's film is all the more affecting for weaving such achingly personal testimony into what is a thoroughly absorbing account of the last great era of human endeavour.
movie_title: The Last Man On The Moon (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Schwartz ... expertly captures the sights, sounds and general bustle of Mali, imbuing her sometimes harrowing film with warmth, intimacy and vitality.
movie_title: They Will Have to Kill Us First (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Rather than being just a cash-in sequel, this episode strikes just the right balance of humour, heart and rollicking set pieces to make it the best of a memorable series.
Craig may be ill-served by the material on this occasion, but his committed performance as the spy hero remains eminently watchable.
For all its flaws, overreaching ambition and excessive running time, this is a prestige picture on a huge scale.
The original members of TV's Horrible Histories make a promising feature debut with this ribald period romp.
Despite sympathetic performances from the two main players, this sprawling crime epic delivers barely enough tension to hold the interest to the end.
There is the odd glaring gap in how events are presented (Shin isn't around to speak for himself), but this story is a real one of a kind.
This offers an often fascinating insider's view of the Who from those who put them on the path to fame.
Though the concert was the catalyst for the film, it provides a portal into a broader and even more compelling story.
A worthy successor, Finding Dory sets its own course, and joyfully delivers.

An intriguing premise, well performed by the actors and engagingly directed by Gansel, suffers from a script that tries to pack too much into a single week and an ending that feels forced and didactic.
Stunning photography and Wong's formidable directing abilities cannot salvage this emotionally empty exercise in style.
Penn's best movie to date rests on a brilliant performance by Hirsch, who gets under the skin of the fascinating character at the centre of the piece.

While there will be those who'll have issues with the film's torpid pacing, those who are willing to submit to Reygadas' astonishing vision will find themselves entranced and ultimately uplifted by the incredible transformative power of his filmmaking.
A promising opening and a stunning performance from Michelle Williams are not enough to rescue a film that jumps restlessly from genre to genre without doing justice to any of its individual stories.
A quietly gripping adversarial duel lies at the heart of this political thriller, which has been hailed as a masterpiece in Vargas's native Mexico.

A worthy but slightly cold adaptation of a classic American novel that fails to fully engage the audience's sympathy despite first-rate performances and some sublime camerawork by multiple Oscar nominee Roger Deakins.

An interesting failure, De Palma's film starts well and has moments of exceptional power but ultimately loses itself in its rambling structure. If you haven't already seen it, you'd probably be better off going back to De Palma's Casualties Of War, which

A grim, slow-burning exploration of guilt, grief and murder that keeps the audience at arm's length through its cold, intermittently misanthropic, vision of humanity but which is filled with ravishing images and a powerfully brooding atmosphere.

Eastwood's swansong performance provides the glue for a foul-mouthed, funny, deeply un-PC and very likeable drama that toys with Eastwood's image as a macho icon and slowly turns audience expectations on their head.

While the filmmakers squander some excellent opportunities that might have helped to illuminate the contradictions in their subject, this remains a fascinating study of an unrepentant American maverick.

A remorselessly grim but deeply affecting psychological horror that's likely to bitterly divide its audience. Not for the faint-hearted, Vinyan is a pitch-black, poetic exploration of the nightmare of losing a child.
A perfectly cast John Malkovich gives a superb performance in a powerful and intelligent study of a man coming back from the brink.
A terrible self-indulgent piece of misogynist trash from an otherwise great director.
A very watchable but frustratingly inconclusive investigation into a classic punk whodunit.
Inglourious Basterds is sprawling, flawed and hugely self-indulgent. It's also hugely enjoyable.
The acting impresses, the plight of the characters, less rounded and sympathetic than they are in the book, merely depresses. Roadworthy then, but hardly revolutionary.
Even Dwayne Johnson couldn't save this sequel.
The Odd Life of Timothy Green, finds Disney at an altogether new low, capped off by a cringeworthy dance sequence that will make you scream for Timothy to crawl back into his magical hole.
movie_title: The Odd Life of Timothy Green (2012)

movie_review_blurb: I'm So Excited works best when it is basking in its screwball, ultra-camp essence. It's unlikely to ruffle any feathers, but boy is it great to see the Director having some fun.
A movie held together thanks to the performances delivered by Felicity Jones and Guy Pearce.
It may not be the sequel that Monsters, Inc. deserves, nor as classic as some of Pixar's previous efforts, but that doesn't mean that it's not worth a place on our cinema screens.
The films greatest achievement is in how deeply mesmerising one woman's story can be, regardless of whether she's famous or not.
For those with a willingness to go with the flow and discover the wonder hiding beneath the surface, This Is Martin Bonner is a triumph of the elegant kind.
Maniac is excelled by a career-altering performance from Wood and an uncomfortable sense of realism that's vested - and maintained - throughout.
A tough watch at times, but it's honest and powerful, with a difficult-to-achieve lightness to it that injects warmth and humour in all the right places.
Despite a few disappointments here and there, the team responsible for Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 have done themselves proud.
movie_title: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: For Those In Peril never outstays its welcome and is slick!
Compliance, for its sheer nerve in tackling such difficult, yet need-to-know material is a terrific film.
It's doubtful that it will be remembered so fondly in years to come (unless it's because of their nonsensical decision to waste Richard Jenkins), but it's fun while it lasts.
An alluring lead performance from Bernal and a suitably low-key, almost purring soundtrack composed by Carlos Cabezas

Disney have struck gold outside of their partnership with Pixar, delivering a riotous, sharp and stirring rollercoaster ride of an animated film, reinforced by clever, sentimental video game references and saccharine delight.
Ang Lee has, for the most part, constructed such a wondrous piece of filmmaking that even the 3D works.
Director Xavier Dolan is fast cementing himself as a writer-director willing to take risks. It might well result in a film that boasts many imperfections, but it's commendable nevertheless.

Gimme the Loot is a slice of lo-fi filmmaking by a promising new talent that refreshingly shifts focus onto the everyday lives of two aspirational young people from a world that's seldom given prominence in film.
Beyond the Hills may not be for everyone, but there's no denying that it's as intoxicating in its suggestions as it is alluring in its depiction of two people segregated by their differing beliefs
Keep the Lights On is an intense, haunting and gut-wrenchingly honest character drama about how addiction can tear love apart.
What makes Brave truly special is that, even if it were stripped of its dazzling visuals, laugh-out-loud humour and dynamism, it would remain a clever, arresting and emotionally involving.
What Berberian Sound Studio accomplishes is a return to a more basic style of film-making than we've become accustomed to in recent years.

The Imposter is one of those rare documentaries that, while its hard to know exactly how much is intensified for the purposes of making the film, is genuinely unsettling and infuriating to believe as fact and fiction.
Once director John Carney returns to his native Dublin for Sing Street, a 1980s set coming-of-age crowdpleaser with real depth, heart and wit to match its toe-tapping musical beats.
A multi-layered and expertly-woven thriller.
As dull as films come, hinged on some primary school level ideas and a range of A-list actors left sputtering out meaningless dialogue.
Hardly original nor necessary, but a fun and absorbing escapade on the Seven Seas.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A slickly directed thriller that bears many of the typical twists and turns you'd expect from a le Carré tale.
