My Life as a Courgette is a tender, funny and wise-beyond-its-years stop-motion animation that takes on tough subject matter through the eyes of a child.
movie_title: My Life as a Zucchini (Ma vie de courgette) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: What the director and writers have done is turn something that's considered by many to be dumb-but-fun into an overlong, unfunny film that's just plain dumb.

A ridiculous creation taken to extraordinary, laugh-a-minute heights.

A feast for the eyes and ears that entertains without asking for anything in return.

So far past its sell-by-date it ought to come with a complimentary funeral wreath.

Outstanding film making and the director's best film in years.

Fast disintegrates into a series of semi-coherent scenes.
A liberal drama that's so safe, the camera was probably wrapped up in cotton wool.

[A] deeply reverent, deeply affecting adaptation.

movie_title: Along the Ridge (Anche libero va bene) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: With its sly wit, dark intelligence and tense action sequences this film re-establishes the Coens as two of American cinema's most talented directors. It's also the best adaptation of McCarthy's work to date and an unmissable crime movie.
Fans deserve better.

An off-centre rom-com with unlikely stars, this indie drama is neither too funny nor too romantic in its balance of laughs and tenderness. The perfect date movie for middle-aged romantics (and we mean that as a compliment).
Although he struggles to make the British-feeling production convince, UK helmer Tom Shankland gets the faux-Fincher nihilism just right.
Both a neat comment on Britain's dilemma in the build-up to the impending war with Germany (to appease or not to appease?) and also a cracking piece of entertainment.
No lavish costume drama, it's instead a theatrical dissection of the spiteful games lovers play.
movie_title: The Duchess of Langeais (Ne Touchez Pas La Hache)(Don't Touch the Axe) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A formally daring attempt to capture the rhythms of adolescence wrapped around a murder mystery, Paranoid Park continues Van Sant's fascination with American youth.

Enter The Dragon meets Shaolin Soccer meets Dodgeball - just with infinitely smaller balls. A camp turn from Christopher Walken astounds but it'll be funnier if you wait for the DVD and lubricate it with a six-pack. Or three.
I Am Legend sees Smith deliver a surprisingly moving performance as he wanders empty New York streets going slowly ga-ga.
A grown-up thriller about morality and the consequences of choice, We Own The Night harks back to an earlier era. A cast of heavy-hitters give it all a solid, polished sheen.
It's all too familiar for its own good, and isn't helped by the screenplay's meandering subplots about the twin sisters' past and their loves in the present.

Touching, tender and laugh-out-loud funny, this little rom-com will melt your heart then rebuild it afresh. It's so warm and inviting, you'll want to spend a week in its company. But you only get 99 minutes. Treasure them.
No Christmas cracker but a likable holiday movie, This Christmas is full of seasonal cheer, some witty banter and a raft of enthusiastic performances from its high-spirited cast.

Fun but instantly forgettable, this retro heist movie illuminates a long-forgotten British blag. Despite a smart set-up, its smash 'n' grab raid on '70s nostalgia leaves little to dissect over a post-movie pint.
The zombies may be dead but George Romero's taste for social commentary certainly isn't in Diary of the Dead, the latest instalment in his long-running walking corpse series.
It's a dumb movie masquerading as smart but failing miserably.
Brilliantly funny, inventive and delirious.
Hides a big heart beneath a small piglet.
Fiendishly unusual, it's an offbeat time-waster that genre fans will definitely want to make a note of.
Never quite the sum of its parts, this would-be intelligent thriller coasts by on strong supporting performances from Giamatti, Sewell and Biel.
This vapid, laugh-lite romp won't satisfy anyone. Except die-hard Jessica Simpson fans.
More sensational than spiritual, this blood-soaked take on the Stations of the Cross retells the Gospels as a horror movie. You can't help asking: where has all the love gone?
Huppert is superb, her lonely heroine both sympathetically vulnerable and yet also slightly culpable for her sons' terribly selfish behaviour.
[Rec] will definitely jangle the nerves. But it's a movie that's unlikely to last in the memory.
A lush and lavish love triangle that has Asia Argento at its tip.
movie_title: Une Vieille Maîtresse (The Last Mistress) (An Old Mistress) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The rapturous camerawork and Chang Chen's performance as Wu both delight, but there's little insight into what makes a game about white and black pebbles so utterly absorbing.

It's not Superbad (and definitely not supergood) but this throwaway romp teases out some laughs as its Frat Pack star heads back to the classroom. Drillbit could try harder but it's definitely not a candidate for exclusion.
Shot like a lush, hypnotic waking dream, it's boldly beautiful and plays some half-smart games with sex, power and gender politics.
Haunting and heartbreaking, The Orphanage delivers a double whammy of chills both real and supernatural.
Lacking gags, proper characters or any comprehensible plot, it never rises above a one-joke movie - and that joke's on us. It's humour Jim, but not as we know it.
movie_title: Captain Eager and the Mark of Voth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Somewhat ironically for a film about insomnia, 4:30 manages to send its audience to sleep. A lack of plot and an ill-judged belief in its own importance make it a disappointment for Tan fans.
This unabashedly liberal documentary tries to redress the balance by giving the rest of America a wake up call: not all scary fundamentalists come strapped with explosives.
A quirky first half of torture, starvation and, um, stinky farts gives way to crazed jungle fever as Dengler leads a great escape into the heart of darkness.
A low-budget Brit-flick that bucks against the usual "urban cinema" conventions while showcasing its talented cast. Although it runs out of steam, its opening energy and verve are impressive.
Lays on the rudeness with gusto earning its 18 certificate, while teasing out the story's themes of nature, sex and class conflict with elegant intelligence.

Reed's take on the material is innovative, letting realism blur into an anaemic, soul-searching delirium. Camera trickery is used to mind-bending effect and Odd Man Out's hallucinatory tone is often astonishing.
Rod's painful, amateur stunts wouldn't look out of place on YouTube. The rest of Samberg's humour is rather more patchy.
Slight yet undeniably touching, this loser comedy has some brittle wit and an odd charm. Deserves a wider audience than it's destined to find.
Matt Damon and Paul Greengrass deliver an action blockbuster with brawn and brains. Whether it's the final chapter or not remains to be seen.
An unconvincing attempt at an old-fashioned western, Seraphim Falls works best as a chase thriller but falls apart when it tries to harness the mythic power of the American frontier.
A return to form and another entry in Schrader's 'God's Lonely Man' saga, this murder mystery is hard not to be intrigued by. Harrelson's brilliant performance is enough to sell it alone.
Surprisingly dreary.
Full of haunting, iconic images and a touch of hopeful humanity, The Seventh Seal is cinema at its most artful, a philosophical meditation on the meaning(lessness) of this mortal coil.
Raw authenticity makes this a strong contender for a Haitian City of God, but it seems too staged and narrow in its focus to properly convince as a documentary.
Bernardo Bertolucci's controversial drama is actually a dark, torrid masterpiece about love and grief.

Stories celebrating heroic journeys are commonplace, but this is a sobering, anti-heroic tale of an ordinary man who set out to attempt the extraordinary... and failed through a cruel combination of bad luck and bad judgement.
A real cinematic oddity, Taxidermia is assured cult status thanks to its disturbing scenes of sex, violence and body horror. It's somewhat slight but it marks Pálfi as a director to watch.
Anyone expecting a reprise of Bruce Almighty will be disappointed.
This take it or leave it romantic comedy probably wouldn't get many Michelin stars, but it's not the turkey twizzler you might expect.

The filmmakers' wide-eyed attempt to turn Leach into a living legend will probably rattle Daily Mail readers' cages; everyone else may find its stonking hard-on for real-life hard men slightly ludicrous.
Bang, bang you're dead: Clive Owen romps his way through Shoot 'Em Up, an outrageously shoddy, audaciously choreographed exploitation flick that loves the smell of gunpowder in the morning.
A chilling picture of coming global crisis fuelled by our lack of fuel.
movie_title: A Crude Awakening: The Oil Crash (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Gloopy and outrageous, this schlock horror tribute is pure trash... in the best possible sense.
movie_title: Planet Terror (Grindhouse Presents: Robert Rodriguez's Planet Terror) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A timely tribute to the 12 men who landed on the moon during the 1960s and 1970s. The remastered, rediscovered documentary footage is incredible, although the absence of Neil Armstrong is disappointing.
movie_title: In the Shadow of the Moon (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It's deeply unsettling; just like a horror movie should be.

Lagerfeld could be the fashion world's Nosferatu: gimlet eyes hidden behind shades as they appraise each new collection; monstrous in his egotism; and, despite his protestations otherwise, painfully lonely after selling his soul to haute couture.
The excessive strobe effects may trigger epileptic fits, but the movie itself will induce narcolepsy.
movie_title: The Seeker: The Dark Is Rising (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Never work with children or animals. Unless you're a child or an animal, in which case, never work with Cuba Gooding Jnr.
It's a weapon of mass distraction, designed to stop you realising this is about as challenging as a GCSE in General Studies.

A film that deserves recognition as one of this country's finest horror movies, a sexually charged Gothic nightmare featuring standout performances from Hammer stalwarts Lee and Peter Cushing, who stars as vampire hunter Van Helsing.
Billed as "Old School American horror", Hatchet's actually something far less classy: a technically inept homage to '80s slasher movies that's both bloody and bloody stupid.
Zombie may not be able to match the stalk 'n' menace of Carpenter's steadicam original, but when the Big Z's knife hits the right groove, he cuts to the dark heart of the Myers legend.
The poverty contrasts sharply with the excitement of the tour bus and cuts to the heart of the songs themselves, famed for their "joy and sorrow".
movie_title: When the Road Bends: Tales of a Gypsy Caravan (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Metal heads will be in Valhalla; everyone else should find a different path.

Too obscure and oblique in its aims to completely enthral, Yella manages to get under the skin thanks to Hoss' bewitching performance as the troubled number cruncher and a final reveal that complicates everything that's gone before.
Pitting Chris against Russ, Yuma harks back to B-movie westerns but fails to tap its A-list stars' potential. Those who aren't diehard fans of the genre might want to catch a different train.
Whitaker pulls off a spectacular thespian coup that has Oscar-winner stamped all over it.
A landmark of world cinema, this is a rousing, staggering epic and a haunting drama of timeless significance.
It's the perfect cinematic vehicle -- or at least it would have been, if Radford's adaptation weren't so unremittingly cloddish.
movie_title: William Shakespeare's The Merchant of Venice (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Showcases Will Ferrell's comedy genius to perfection.
movie_title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Jennie Jacques smoulders as a liplicking bad girl but the sad truth is that this below-par horror doesn't dare do anything memorable.
How does a small Chinese guy become the movies' greatest martial artist of all time? That question drives this reverential documentary about the man with the one-inch punch.
It's a confessional portrait of the artist as a nutty middle-aged man and a rare insight into a controversial director who's as divisive as the 38th Parallel.
Love in this teen flick is less like a red, red rose than a bloody nose.
The invisiblecamera approach begs questions yet, for the most part, the effects are extraordinary.
Despite its delusions, this is no Ghost Protocol.
This exploitation flick is a red-blooded, all-American revenge movie, but offers sensitive insight into the pain of post-war adjustment.
It doesn't amount to much, though the post-punk soundtrack adds bite.
Totally oddball, this Japanese comedy's jokes occasionally get lost in translation, yet it moves effortlessly from colonic irrigation to crowd-pleasing, clam-packing sing-alongs with quirky verve.
movie_title: Kawa no soko kara konnichi wa (Sawako Decides) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's abhorrent, hilarious and destined for cult status.
This is far from original, but the claustrophobic setting and bloody prosthetic carnage should entertain undemanding horror fans.
Inflation may have dented the allure of its 1m bullion heist, but this 1951 Ealing comedy is still 24-carat gold.
If Ken Russell remade The Bunker it might look like this.
Forceful stuff, though we can take or leave the kale sandwiches.
A whimsical tale of Celtic self-reliance vs English stuffiness, this wee comedy dram warms the heart as surely as a blended malt.
It succeeds in spite of itself and it's all thanks to Chaney. The man of a thousand faces imbues this character with bravado and menace.
Making Mega Shark Vs Giant Octopus look like Jaws, it is totally lost at sea.
An important contribution to the avant-garde, this existential thriller offers an allegorical take on the cruel and twisted universe in which we live.
movie_title: Woman in the Dunes (Suna no Onna) (1964)

movie_review_blurb: The stark triumph of Children of Men lies in how its visceral vérité style brings the realities of a War on Terror fought in distant lands crashing back onto British soil.
This is really a one joke movie -- but that single gag is delivered with such caustic rancour by director Zwigoff that it achieves sublime heights of comedy.
It's psychological horror at its finest: timelessly terrifying and absolutely purr-fect.
With its tense score, contrasting performances of Chahine (twitchy and tightly coiled) and Rostom (sexy but cruel) and audacious moments of formal brilliance Cairo Station is a cinematic triumph.
movie_title: Bab el hadid (Cairo Station) (The Iron Gate) (1958)

movie_review_blurb: The dull romance between Sadie and Ben is revealed as little more than a prop for the comedian's patented schtick.
Depressingly, these magpie parodies are so cheap to produce they can't fail to make money -- which probably means this interminable franchise is far from over.
Those unfamiliar with the work may be completely bewildered, but stick with it -- this is a bold and uncompromising take on one of the genre's sacred cows that stands up to repeat viewings.
Denmark's charmless answer to The Hangover crosses the line between gross-out and just plain gross.
An important, moving doc about how LGBT activism taught a community to shun silence.
Tragic yet hilarious, it's like watching Hunter S. Thompson's bucket list.
Alfredson's light touch adds soulful delicacy and a certain ambiguity to the proceedings, making this a horror movie more likely to prompt tears than screams.
This re-establishes The Simpsons as the jewel in the crown of American animation.
Spider-Man director Sam Raimi returns to his Evil Dead roots in this yucky, energetic and consistently entertaining fright movie.
Ingmar Bergman's haunting masterpiece explores the gulf of communication that exists between a nurse and her silent patient.
Isao Takahata's powerful anti-war movie is all the more harrowing for the care we invest in its beautifully drawn children.
movie_title: Grave of the Fireflies (Hotaru no haka) (1988)

movie_review_blurb: Butts' moving doc exposes the tragedy of the experiments - not least of all horrific birth defects - as he follows a deformed local woman intent on having a child despite the risks.
World's End is duller than a Disneyland ride during a power cut.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The re-creation of the 1960s backdrop on a tight budget sadly never allows the director to unleash the epic sweep this against-the-odds yarn really requires.

The migraine-inducing visuals and game-heavy dialogue -"I can use this trap card to summon Stardust Dragon, and now he's going to attack with cosmic flare" - will leave most non-fans clawing their eyes out.
It's the action that really suffers, the anime's dynamism fizzling out as every samurai duel falls back on fake-looking CG squibs and a blur of fast-cut, see-nothing camera angles.
Beep, beep, wooooooo...: this moronic medical horror's so awful, you'll be willing yourself to flatline.
Director Rupert Murray brings the fear with disturbing stats'n'graphics.
Tender and moving, this offbeat gem isn't afraid to swap its docu-realism for outlandish fantasy.
This is not about the incalculable emptiness of the void. Space here is nothing more than an extension of the western frontier and manifest destiny, a place where men can be brave and women admiring.

Long, lyrical takes - including a startling shot of a floating funeral procession - and Schubert's 'Death And The Maiden' on the soundtrack remind us that forbidden passion will only end in tears. The Danube's rarely seemed so blue.
A British-Asian comedy that may not be mad or sad but is... Well, you've guessed it. another underachieving comedy to file and forget in British cinema's already overstuffed bottom drawer. Yawn.
Bloated, overblown and essentially empty, Fellini's last hit movie skims over the surface of the lives it depicts, substituting manufactured sentiment for genuine feeling or understanding.
Latin American middle-class panic needs no translation in this strong thriller about the worries of the wealthy. Fans of JG Ballard's novels will relish it.
Rubbish CGI, rubbish acting, rubbish storytelling. Throw in a few mutants and a better-than-it-deserves cast and you get this sci-fi timewaster.
A dead scary horror movie that skimps on the blood but not the goose bumps,

Arty-smarty and impeccably French, this collection of horror 'toons delivers some short, sharp shocks amid the occasional misfire. It's worth seeing for Burns' section alone. Just repeat, it's only a cartoon...
movie_title: Peur(s) du Noir (Fear(s) of the Dark) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Grants all three wishes and some more besides with a brilliant turn from Williams' genie and some beautiful animation.

[Morgen and Burstein] reinvigorate the usual menu of archival footage with a 3-D cutout style that imbues inert black and white stills with a playful, camp dynamism.
movie_title: The Kid Stays in the Picture (2002)

movie_review_blurb: A crisp and credible behind-the-scenes drama.
Sentimentality and the comedy of deception conspire to enchanting effect.
Benoit Jacquot serves up Puccini's warhorse with a minimum of cinematic hoo-ha and a maximum of respect.
Such a class act on so many levels that it feels as fresh and stirring as your first-ever baseball flick.
An artificial exercise in personal childhood reverie whose squishy, generic personality shows evidence aplenty of corporate fingerprints.
Shatteringly realistic action sequences lift this fictionalized treatment of the Serbian-Croatian fighting notches above its sentimental domestic framing device.

You've got the most percussive navel-gazer in independent film bringing together such type-A personalities as Zack Norman and Ron Silver, and then having them toot their trombones at each other for the better part of 90 minutes.
The underpinning misogyny of 40 Days and 40 Nights is only exceeded by its cynicism.

There are labors of love and there are labors of labor, exhaustively worked-through movies in which you feel as if you are watching a director give birth to every idea that has been gestating in the brain since he was given his first 8-mm camera.
There are enough throwaway references to faith and rainbows to plant smile-button faces on that segment of the populace that made A Walk to Remember a niche hit.
The performers are so spot on, it is hard to conceive anyone else in their roles.
Anyone who has ever been stalked on the highway by a twirling red light and a siren should find satisfaction in this send-up of state trooper foibles.

Benefiting from Nicola Pavani's poignant scoring and the telling understatement of Giuseppe Lanci's cinematography, it's a lovely work, nonetheless, a welcome creative departure for a gifted Italian artist.
movie_title: La Stanza del Figlio (The Son's Room) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: It is not the first time that director Sara Sugarman stoops to having characters drop their pants for laughs and not the last time she fails to provoke them.
It's not even another teen movie. Its shamelessness is in a class by itself.
If there was a flu shot for the blues, it might come in the form of this embraceable ode to loneliness and love regained.
It's a big production, but the movie feels somewhat counterfeit.
Fudges fact and fancy with such confidence that we feel as if we're seeing something purer than the real thing.
An engrossing, elegantly detailed, intermittently sappy dramatization of the heroism of Czech bomber pilots and the ignominious fate that awaited many of them in the years following the war.
A dreary Aristotelian tragedy whose contemporary geopolitical relevance cannot compensate for the lack of gripping protagonists.
A formula comedy as affable and ineffectual as its hero.
An eloquent and unshakable obituary to a reign of terror that defies comprehension.
movie_title: Kandahar: Le soleil derrière la lune (2001)

movie_review_blurb: This parody of teen comedies is just teen comedy by the numbers, for those who can only count to three.
Majidi's poetic love story is a ravishing consciousness-raiser, if a bit draggy at times.
A showcase for three diamond-solid actors.
Rarely has leukemia looked so shimmering and benign.
A disconcertingly riveting anti-love story.

Like its middle-aged protagonist, the film goes a little flabby in its center, but is kept compelling by the quirky charisma of Serge Lizrovet as a con man who comes to Vincent's aid, and the chameleonic smoothness of its star.
There are so many self-consciously screwy conceits begging for laughs in this lunatic fringe Miami Vice, the prize for crudest is anyone's call.
A gorgeous eyeful and earful of a gangster drama.
The all-French cast is marveilleux.
movie_title: Skin of Man, Heart of Beast (1999)

movie_review_blurb: A beguiling splash of pastel colors and prankish comedy from Disney.
They crush each other under cars, throw each other out windows, electrocute and dismember their victims in full consciousness. And we don't avert our eyes for a moment.
For all its fabulous outerwear, The Emperor's New Clothes feels very hand-me-down.
A dopey movie clothed in excess layers of hipness.
This engrossing, characteristically complex Tom Clancy thriller is shifty in the manner in which it addresses current terrorism anxieties and sidesteps them at the same time.
That rare instance where Hollywood improves upon a movie from foreign soil.
What Wilde regarded as 'a trivial comedy for serious people,' Parker has made over into a trivial comedy for trivial people.
A shrewd (if uneven) hybrid of American savvy and British savoir-faire.
Walsh can't quite negotiate the many inconsistencies in Janice's behavior or compensate for them by sheer force of charm.

These self-styled athletes have banged their brains into the ground so frequently and furiously, their capacity to explain themselves has gone the same way as their natural instinct for self-preservation.
It's a charmed and frequently charming journey, but like Naipaul's flawed hero, the film suffers from unchecked ambition.
A coming-of-age tale from New Zealand whose boozy, languid air is balanced by a rich visual clarity and deeply felt performances across the board.
Another in-your-face wallow in the lower depths made by people who have never sung those blues.
As convoluted in its own way as Memento, and almost as sardonically funny.
A painfully funny ode to bad behavior.
The setup feels a little been-there-done- that, but the writing is often piercing and there are unsparing characterizations by Julianne Moore and James LeGros.
Like the Chelsea's denizens ... Burdette's collage-form scenario tends to over-romanticize the spiritual desolation of the struggling artiste.
This is Sandra Bullock at her teasing, wonder woman best.
De-lovely to look at, deliciously cast, but something less than delightful.
Citizen Kane for fans of Agatha Christie and Liz Smith: no frills, but juicy.
As charming, humorous and heimisch as its nomadic subjects.
A sparkling cosmopolitan comedy that plays fast and loose with sacred cows of family values.
Bruno-Tedeschi has one of those alert, off-kilter screen faces that burn with light and intelligence even as their characters slide into darkness: a tragedienne of the first order.
Provocative and ambitious.
Rodriguez, whose prankish production design was the real star of the original Spy Kids, has become a prisoner of his 3-D mandate.
movie_title: The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl in 3-D (2005)

movie_review_blurb: [An] exercise in do-it-yourself-justice-mongering.
If Rod Serling had had a shot at penning a post-9/11 scenario for The Twilight Zone, it might have come out something like this compact and creepy suspense thriller of apocalypse, Los Angeles-style.
The fumbling banalities spouted by the characters belie the prior achievements of the actors making them up.
Dedication is peppered with drolly passive-aggressive supporting characters and actors equipped to do them full justice.
Paging John O'Hara. One would have to reach back to those melodramatic family potboilers of the '50s to find such an unfettered blast of guilt-tripping and misdirected love.
The prickly camaraderie between Buscemi and Pitt puts Delirious back on track, abetted by a hilarious turn by Gina Gershon.
Dans Paris feels fresh and quirky enough to have been made 30 years ago.

Blitz's one-man revenge of the nerds continues with this narrative-feature debut, a smartypants comedy about a kid with a lot going on inside and a sadly undependable mouthpiece with which to let it out.
Stardust comes as close as any newfangled fairy tale in recent years to sating the appetite of dream-hungry moviegoers.
As one might anticipate with a comedy about children and the outdoors, a lot of screen time is devoted to bodily noises and throwing up.
Lapica's lack of distance from his story is both the film's strength and its weakness.
The vibrant music ultimately takes a back seat to the cacophonous lady at the film's misplaced center
I Know Who Killed Me, ostensibly a horror thriller in the slice-and-dice vein of Captivity and Saw, bagged as many laughs in its bloodbath finale as anything in The Simpsons Movie.

Festooned with oodles of museum-worthy 17th century sets and costumes, Moliere is the sort of slightly naughty but literate frolic that congratulates the audience for its good taste; in other words, it's a bit of a snooze.
...words speak even louder than visual evidence in Charles Ferguson's lacerating analysis of America's occupation of Iraq.

Meadows' electric drama takes the audience with it from the percolating opening moments through its hopeful (if ever-so-contrived) denouement, filling the landscape with memorably engaging characters and potent ensemble performances.

...may be less potty-mouthed than South Park: Bigger, Longer and Uncut, but it takes aim at its middle-American milieu with a towel-snapping glee that is just as effective in reducing its audience to cheerfully willing victims.
Arctic Tale is yet another wildlife orgy of ooh-ing and aah-ing designed to expose young ones to the lifestyles of the furry and the fabulous.

Every frame wows with exquisite arrangements of light and color; each of the characters' choices is packed with a sense of consequence and urgency that makes us feel as if we're frittering away our lives by comparison.

First-time filmmaker Jorge Gaggero manages to distill a remarkable quantity of poetic gold and psychological truth from this simplest of set-ups, peeling away the shared history of these women with brief but telling snippets of information.

How ironic that Richard Lester had to go all the way to England to make that chef-d'oeuvre of sex comedies, The Knack... and How to Get It, while Ellis stays home and churns out the British answer to American Pie.
...Hairspray is a surprisingly effervescent ice cream soda of a musical, fizzing with sly comic performances and a bonanza of heel-thumping numbers.
Screenwriter Tony Gilroy, who's been around the block with Bourne on the first two pictures, juggles all of this to-ing and fro-ing with admirable precision.

The difficulties that men of a certain age have in forging substantive alliances is a subject rarely tackled by the movies in any serious way, so one is inclined to forgive Leconte the film's sitcommy tendencies.
It's a boozy, weekend-bender of an action flick, lovely to look at and perhaps just a little bit silly.
It's karaoke with a vengeance, the circle of the inferno that Dante could never in his wildest imaginings anticipate.
Reduces issues of burning domestic urgency to a rubble of burnt melodrama.
None of this is as amusing as the writers ostensibly imagine it to be.
Purely as an exercise in stylistic face-lifting, Sleuth is fascinating.
Silence would be a blessing to Elizabeth: The Golden Age, which substitutes symphonic din in place of drama.

What's remarkable about Lars and the Real Girl is the tightrope that [screenwriter Nancy] Oliver finesses, aided by her director and winning cast, between improbability and reality, edgy absurdist humor and melting tenderness. It's a tonic.

Director David L. Cunningham keeps it all moving right along, but it's still malarkey.
movie_title: The Seeker: The Dark Is Rising (2007)

movie_review_blurb: [A] mysterious, gripping meta-documentary, a movie that reflects upon the thorny, unpredictable process of capturing a real-life story on film at the same time it's trying to figure out what the story is.
It's invigorating and impressive on a formal level, but ultimately wearying.
Screenwriter Matthew Michael Carnahan wants us to know that there are good Arabs and bad Arabs, but he panders to our basest 9/11 anxieties.
Moves like a barn on fire.
It's a sexed-up, dumbed-down Dr. T and the Women, with penguins to pacify women who've been railroaded into going to this movie by their loutish boyfriends.

The Assassination of Jesse James is less of a Western than a mid-Western, which refers both to the film's urban Missouri center of gravity and its pivoting position between horse opera and backstage intrigue.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Sydney White is a carnival of ethnic and social stereotypes rising up against the lily-white status quo.
In Paul Haggis' In the Valley of Elah, Jones' face is a poignantly detailed map of skepticism, simmering rage and, in the final count, self-recrimination.
The stilted dialogue makes all of the actors sound as if they're being dubbed into English, badly, especially the English-speaking ones (Alfred Molina, looking seriously bored).
This round-robin of marital malaise has more integrity than one might expect from its meet-cute beginnings.
Whether in cloaked repose or naked defense, Mortensen dares you to take your eyes off of him.
A cheapjack vigilante potboiler.
The Bubble, which manages to be effortlessly breezy without shortchanging on topicality, epitomizes [Director] Fox's adroit talent for juxtaposing the personal and the political.
A smart and tense diversion, albeit in a vaguely irresponsible way.
A textbook example of the hazards of hiring a writer to adapt his own novel.
Into the Wild is a bittersweet odyssey of opportunities lost and paradise found.
Drama/Mex can't see past its nihilistic little nose.
Rescued from hagiography and cliche by tart writing and a spark-plug star performance from Don Cheadle.
...The Method is a tartly performed, compulsively watchable glass-tower And Then There Were None, in which the only blood that gets spilt comes from places that hurt the most: pride and ego.
For all its roiling tensions, Jindabyne is an oddly antiseptic, even repressed, experience.
A breakneck action-comedy that could put the final digit on Lethal Weapon and its kind, if there is any mercy.

While Fracture walks a thin line between fulfilling expectations and confounding them, screenwriter Daniel Pyne does a reasonably good job in balancing the battle of wits between his rising legal-eagle and his calculating wife-killer.
It hurtles toward its foregone denouement with such a whirligig gust of madcap spirits, you might need to readjust your hair as you head out of the theater.
A sexy and cunningly disorienting thriller that provokes the viewer into a state of anxious participation from first to last frame.
[Director] Fox's ensemble, led by Steph Song as the whale-watching cutie, exudes easy, impish charm. Vancouver plays itself, for a change, to a postcard-radiant fare-thee-well.
The murder clues are trotted out in dishonestly protracted fashion by screenwriter Todd Komarnicki, who plants red herrings as malodorous as a fish market at 5 in the morning.
By the end, you may feel as if you've been ballroom dancing with a live, exposed electric guitar cord for an hour and a half. At peak performance, it's wired, chaotic madness.
movie_title: Aqua Teen Hunger Force Colon Movie Film for Theaters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A favorite on the film festival circuit, Alexandra Lipsitz's exuberantly funny documentary follows the triumphant path of an American air guitarist as he rises from U.S. East Coast champ to the top rankings of the international air guitar festival.
[Director Peter Miller] shrewdly exposes the monolithic, class-driven legal machinery that sent a pair of innocent, hard-working immigrants to the chair.
Time is of the essence in the new sci-fi thriller Next, and all the major players wear expensive watches to prove it.
Crisply written and acted soap opera from Susanne Bier, but vague in its intentions.
It is a testament to the robotic constraints of Pride that even Terrence Howard sinks in the service of formula.

Goes about its business with a welcomely wry humor that undercuts the scenario's earnest New Age-y potential. If it isn't always crystal clear about what's on its mind, it speaks its heart in a language that kids totally get.

The schematic requirements of the setup, combined with the tight-lipped demeanor of the two lead characters, makes for arid moviegoing. Eighty-five minutes can seem much longer than it really is when you spend the entire time waiting for a shoe to drop.
movie_title: The Page Turner (La Tourneuse de pages) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: To what niche does this movie aspire, Michael Crichton sci-fi chiller, Ed Wood camp or neo-'60s grand guignol for former leading ladies of a certain age? You decide.
Rock's depiction of women as either pouting spoilsports, nagging, frigid soccer moms or man-eating vixens harkens back to the pre-feminist '60s.
movie_title: I Think I Love My Wife (2007)

movie_review_blurb: American Cannibal would be interesting if it weren't so 2001.
movie_title: American Cannibal: The Road to Reality (2006)

movie_review_blurb: For all its roughhouse antics, Adam's Apples is almost improbably sweet: a rude comedy that the devout and heathen alike can hold to their breasts.

Folks who are heavily invested in stereotypes of thuggish terrorists may balk at Loach's portrait of articulate IRA ideologues. But there is no denying his ferocious grip on our emotions. Barley is one tough and beautiful film.
movie_title: The Wind That Shakes the Barley (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The actors are so engaging and the settings often so seductive, we pleasurably submit to what is essentially a two-hour penance for all the hurt and wrongs one has ever inflicted upon one's parents.
Trumps Hotel Rwanda in its you-are-there immediacy and unflinching gaze.
Character nuance and sly wit trump plot novelty in this immensely satisfying suspense drama.

Promoted as an intellectual suspense thriller, Emmanuel Bourdieu's second feature film is a chilling plunge into the dark pools of group think and a scalding examination of the vulnerability of the unformed identity.

How invigorating it is to see portrayed such a range of complex, intelligent women, each of whom is surviving in an independent orbit rather than joined at the hip in some gooey movie idyll of sisterhood.

Asks the piercing question: does the terrorist lurk within us? In actuality, it's a question worth exploring, but not one that this bombastic and silly thriller is prepared to answer in any dramatically sustainable fashion.
All of this goes down very, very slowly. Joshua aspires to be a kind of Rosemary's Baby's Older Brother by way of Gaslight, but it lacks the dynamism and atmosphere of either of those inspirations.
If you know the original, then you may receive this gripping and faithful dramatization as a kind of cinematic experiment in the relative merits of the spoken word vs. the illustrated.
Keith Thompson's screenplay is a tad over-populated, but Cherie Nowlan's film settles in and gathers force as it goes along.
License to Wed is another lamebrain Hollywood comedy in which a peanut gallery of the shrill and the narcissistic conspire to drive a wedge between two innocents.
The flaw is underscored by the one-bod-fits-all casting that renders everyone indistinguishable, especially when they have their clothes off (which is a good deal of the picture).
To those of us for whom there can never be enough film dramas with a classical music backdrop, Vitus comes as a bit of a disappointment.
What a blessing this film is, for everyone who's chosen the road less taken, and even perhaps for anyone who's stood in their way.
movie_title: The Real Dirt on Farmer John (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A film of sun-dappled beauty and unbridled joys that arrive as much as a surprise to the audience as they do to the characters.
Angelina Jolie's intelligently tucked-in performance as Mariane avoids grandstanding, receding instead into the intricate tapestry of Michael Winterbottom's tense and authentically relayed film.
1408 is not quite interesting enough to linger long in the mind, but it has enough jack-in-the-box chills to mollify those who feel it's been all downhill since The Uninvited.

Of all the Marvel-spawned screen franchises, the Fantastic Four is the most puerile, reducing as it does this smartly quirky comic book quartet to a fourth-grade primer in dysfunctional family psychology.
movie_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It has a pumping dynamism that keeps you with it.
Everyone is having so much fun, one would really like to be a part of it. But the performance sequences are too jaggedly truncated to pull us in entirely.
movie_title: When the Road Bends: Tales of a Gypsy Caravan (2007)

movie_review_blurb: This Nancy is indistinguishable from every other Teen Vogue cheerleader tapped by Hollywood for role model of the month over the last 20 years. Casting agents, are there no budding Jodie Fosters in the entirety of America's high school drama clubs?

For two hours, life as you drearily know it is effectively suspended and a summery delirium takes over. This may be one of the busiest movies ever made, but Soderbergh keeps the activity percolating with a fizzy arsenal of retro editing flourishes.
A spry, animated surfing-doc send-up, complete with dull-headed surfer dudes, cannibal birds and a reject from Chicken Run.
Marion Cotillard is a knockout in this scintillating and soulful musical bio.

Buñuel watchers will cluck with pleasure at that one; neophytes can revel in the steely elegance of [actor] Piccoli, who at 80 (when this film was made) effervesces with the joy of his craft. Belle Toujours glistens with discreet charms.

If Winter had an extraordinary youth, it eludes Brooklyn Rules, another generic memory piece in which the now-successful writer takes us on a thinly veiled tour of the burger joints, bowling alleys and faces from his formative grunge years.
Christopher Smith's Severance is an odd but entirely welcome duck: a horror spoof that strays into zones of political and ethical consequence, without ever becoming mired in them.
As it is, we are left to wonder why neither Tom's wife nor anyone working at Chip's office are not able to see through his machinations.
Good-natured but curiously flat, a bottle of root beer that's lost its fizz.
A screeching and wearyingly hyperbolic exercise in film-school nihilism that finds buried meaning in the term overkill.
An arduous melodrama set in a high-tax-bracket corner of Connecticut.
It's borderline parody of a kind of fey filmmaking popular at crunchy-granola festivals, but the counterfeit aesthetic is ultimately outshone by the life-affirming message.
Family, and the core ideals that hold them in place, are blown to smithereens by the robbery at the ravaged heart of Sidney Lumet's scalding new thriller.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: As much a pungent dissection of American media malaise as it is a towering tribute to a deceptively low-burning leader.
This broadly amoral take on Breakfast at Tiffany's suffers from a serious case of who-should-we-care-for: He's a sap, she's a soulless vamp, their patrons are either cruel, self-deluding or both.
Stop-Loss builds a cumulative power and sense of urgency that can't be denied.
Under Luketic's flaccid direction, 21 is another two-faced moralistic entertainment that shows us how much fun it is to live large, then punishes its characters for acting out our fantasies.
Meet the Browns is saddled with the usual quotient of phony snafus and entanglements that are easily untangled.
Heartbeat Detector earns its points, arriving at a potent conclusion with a stealth and meticulousness that knocks the wind out of you.

The Grand lacks any sort of urgency or inner propulsiveness; the actors do their little goofs, then hand them off to the next, lending the jest the frolicking but ultimately monotonous quality of a game of tag.
The picture grows on you, as does its laconic leading lady, whose slurry delivery conceals an ever-alert mouse handily equipped to beat the cat at his own game.
For a film roiling with so much turmoil of the heart, Love Songs generates dismayingly little emotional frisson.
A drama of mother-son love that lunges for the heart from its pulsating curtain raiser to its leap-for-joy fade out.
Much as one might admire the British health care system as presented in the documentary Sicko, even Michael Moore would have to admit they have a hard time over there coping with apocalyptic viruses.
A comedy of low blows and elephantine misfires.
Never see movies that give stupid macho advice in their titles.
An epic adventure of such towering testosterone counts and ceaseless tedium, you can almost feel the hair growing on your chest as the bags collect beneath your eyes.

Writer-director David Gordon Green's brave and magnificently performed period piece (mid-'70s) witnesses an adolescent's first romance as it blossoms amid a dissonant backdrop of disintegrating marriages.
The heat of empathetic outrage that Li generates from the audience is enough to make the theater combust.
It is safe to say that no one makes movies quite like Hong Kong's clown impresario Stephen Chow.
Director Bharat Nalluri compounds the chintziness with a full-throttle approach that blows away any lingering nuance from the source material.
movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The kind of comfy, reassuring take on human relations that makes cynics want to growl at the stranger sitting next to them.
Beneath the thundering horse hoofs and happy wedding fiddles is a viper's nest of sexual intrigue that would be at home on Desperate Housewives.

It's already been compared to Brazilian classics City of God and Pixote. But Chop Shop is both more hopeful and less punishing than those films, in no small measure owing to the synergy between first-time actors Polanco and Gonzales.

The Duchess of Languor might be more evocative. Faithfully lifted from the pages of Honore de Balzac, Jacques Rivette's overlong, resplendently decorative drama takes on the phlegmatic air of its character.
movie_title: The Duchess of Langeais (Ne Touchez Pas La Hache)(Don't Touch the Axe) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The Signal is a well-oiled example of that oxymoronic Tarantino phenomenon: the arty grindhouse picture.
Funny Games is about as hostile a jest as has ever been aimed at American audiences by a foreign director. The joke wouldn't be half as galling were it not so expertly written and executed.
[A] glossy but overly efficient drama that, like Nazneen's husband, is ultimately too ineffectual to make much of a dent.

Wackness is ultimately less evocative of pre-Sept. 11 Manhattan than it is of post-Sept. 11 Park City, Utah, where the film had its Sundance debut, and where festival audiences never tire of rebel-male angst and bluesy, guitar-inflected scoring.
By the time Carter and co-writer Frank Spotnitz throw in cartoon Russian villains and a risible plot point involving same-sex marriage, it's hard to figure where they, or their movie, is coming from.
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Pickering's wide, tremulous eyes reflect the film's lurid appeal to youthful terrors.
Through all, Liu is a commanding and ever-changing mask of reactions as a woman who observes her suitors as if looking out from the protective shield of a dark-tinted window.
Anthony Hopkins is devastatingly demonic in Jonathan Demme's truly horrifying thriller.
Amid all this dazzling artifice, the film's most authentic source of power comes from its star.
A unique alchemy seems to take hold on those sporadic occasions when the Coen brothers decide to get down with their ethnic roots.
A deserved prizewinner at Sundance, Saavedra seems to age 25 years and then drop 35 in the space of an hour and a half.

Taking co-directorial reins with Panna Rittikrai, Jaa has erected a portentous platform for his high-flying athleticism, bearing none of the freewheeling spirit or humor that made his feature debut a guiltless pleasure.
Playing identical twin brothers who have landed on very different ends of the personality spectrum, Norton gives two bravura comic performances, shoulder-to-shoulder...
A get-rich-quick picture about a guy with get-rich-quick dreams. The moon may shine high over Ralph Kramden's New York City, but sights are set depressingly low in the studio schemes of Hollywood.
If the filmmakers do little to expand the vocabulary of the genre, they enhance our appreciation of that most undervalued sector of the American workforce, the city schoolteacher.

Iranian American director Cyrus Nowrasteh has amplified the basic elements of Suraya's story into the worst kind of exploitive Hollywood melodrama, presented under the virtuous guise of moral outrage.
In fashioning a comeback for Vardalos, writer Mike Reiss has cribbed much from her Greek Wedding playbook.
Soderbergh taps into the nervy impulses of his earliest endeavor, sex, lies and videotape as well as Ocean's Eleven. The Girlfriend Experience has something to elevate and exasperate fans of both.
It is as if the director had studied the comedies of Eric Rohmer and Woody Allen from top to bottom and come away with all the wrong lessons.
movie_title: Un Baiser s'il vous plaît (Shall We Kiss?) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Those who fondly recall The Blob would seem to be the target crowd for a fastidious pastiche that attempts to coax laughs by maintaining a poker face.
Gomorrah manages to be artful without being arty.
The movie has Johnson, who lifts the script above its conventional cat-and-mouse stratagems with his buoyant wiseacre timing.
An arduous cheerleader comedy geared toward those too green to know that cheerleader comedies went out long before the last pompom shake of Bring It On.
When an actor reaches a summit of unparalleled global popularity, it is probably hard to resist the temptation to play God.
Gervais is a master of the flustered broken thought, and Koepp takes full advantage in scenes that pit Pincus against a distracted doctor (a droll Kristen Wiig) and an imposingly large dog.
A familiar but taut thriller sparked by a quartet of committed lead performances and the visual acrobatics of stealth camera ace Declan Quinn.
It is the cozy marriage of sensibilities between the director of Clerks and the co-writer/star of Superbad that gives this movie its particular go-for-the-groin, land-on-the-heart chemistry.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A queasy-making train thriller directed with vibrant visual panache by Brad Anderson.
This high school dramedy feels strangely earthbound, despite an articulate script and an engaging cast.
For all the vomiting and the runny noses, Two Weeks feels a little too cozy to fully pass muster as art.
An assassination thriller that boasts the glossy tourist vistas of an airline magazine combined with a serious case of instant-replay-itis.

It presumes, with misguided cynicism, that Rice's oafish choices reflect the smoldering fantasies of any average guy who might wish to jump himself out of an unforgiving, single-parent household in Ann Arbor, Mich.
Most everything in I Am Legend feels lifted from elsewhere.
Israeli filmmaker Eran Kolirin has made a sly and bewitching chamber comedy that underscores the decency of its characters while sidestepping the gooey, let's-join-hands imperative of its premise.
Cusack has never been better; he disappears into his character's repressed skin so utterly, we can barely recognize in him the perky teen heartthrob of Say Anything.
The Golden Compass works up enough self-important gravitas to power the entire Lord of the Rings cycle. Weitz's deflatingly anticlimactic windup assures us there is more to come.
If you have an ax to grind with someone who harbors a morbid fear of surgery, you couldn't design a better revenge than taking them to see Awake.
The visual lyricism and irascible humor of Julian Schnabel's screen adaptation make for a life-against-the-odds drama like none you've ever seen.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Has the patina of authenticity, but Wagner's characters speak in banalities that describe their all-too-familiar plights from the outside without getting inside their skins, as if they are trapped in the expositional stages of an old Broadway play.
A tense and mammothly upsetting dramatization of Tamburrini's memoir; ... gets everything that can pound in your body pounding.

The film's final third contains a glimmer of a great movie wanting to break out.

movie_review_blurb: Martin McDonagh's raucous dark comedy teeters between cheeky humor and violence, overplaying both to varying degrees.

movie_review_blurb: A film of abundant heart and exquisite faces.

movie_review_blurb: Harrowing and heart-stopping.

U23D only just begins to tap the potential of performance film in three dimensions, but the possibilities are thrilling to contemplate.

The impression that lingers is that of an artist clutching fast to yesterday's inspirations.

Reha Erdem's ineffably beautiful portrait of a rural Turkish village.

[Katt] Williams blithely walks off with the second half of First Sunday, which more or less walks in place until he arrives.

Mr. Murphy knows exactly what he's doing, and he wins at every turn.

Mr. Bridges may not have breathed fire into this material, but he has preserved most of its better qualities. He has treated it with intelligence, respect and no undue reverence, assembling a coherent film that resists any hint of exploitation.
Kubrick worked in an uncharacteristically naturalistic style despite the genre material, with mixed but still fascinating results.
Stylish and eerily compelling before it overplays its campy excesses, Heavenly Creatures does have a feverish intensity to recommend it.

Here comes a sequel that's worth its salt. The second Star Trek movie is swift, droll and adventurous, not to mention appealingly gadget-happy. It's everything the first one should have been and wasn't.
movie_title: Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan (1982)

movie_review_blurb: Mr. Reynolds has appeared in a long string of stinkers in recent years, but this time, the trouble isn't his fault.

While the prospect of watching Miss Hawn play a rude, nasty socialite is appealing, and even the transformation to homebody is a funny idea, Overboard winds up taking things too far.
Street Smart winds up being a bit too smart for its own good, but it's compelling and complex.
On its own terms, it's a considerable success, though it's a film that sacrifices everything in the interests of style.

A sweeping, glorious-looking western that's at least a full generation removed from the classic films it brings to mind.

movie_review_blurb: There's none of Django Unchained's revenge fantasies or tomfoolery here, only a sober depiction of the cruelty and oppression that defined a long and very ugly chapter of American history.

Though the influence of Italian neorealism is clear in Wadjda's unshowy style and generosity of spirit, this film remains a singular achievement for all the best reasons.

Though the general anxiety level doesn't run quite as high in Enough Said as it did in Holofcener's brilliant 2010 effort, Please Give, there's still a fine balance of the same acerbic humour and messy emotional vulnerability.

Its scenes of bloodied doctors, panicked aides, and devastated Secret Service Agents are gripping, but Parkland is marred by Landesman's efforts to ensure that the historical importance of every moment is not lost on viewers.
An action-packed look at the men who do their best to keep Detroit from going up in flames.
Watermark succeeds both as a rumination on our varied relationship with H2O and as a warning about the perils we'll face when we're down to the last few drops.
Sample This contains a wealth of revelations about music and musicians with which most people are intimately familiar yet know little about.

An affable if only passably funny effort that reunites Jason Sudeikis with his Horrible Bosses co-star Jennifer Aniston, We're the Millers rides much the same highway as National Lampoon's Vacation did in an earlier era of raunchy road comedies.
Elysium is yet another badly derivative and poorly engineered contraption in a summer movie season that's already thick as blackflies with 'em.
While the pleasures of Silva's trippy road-trip movie are mostly minor, it still does something major by eliciting Cera's boldest performance to date.
Iron Man 3 displays no shortage of cocky swagger in-between - and often during - the requisite sequences of high-tech 3-D carnage.

It's no small feat for the audacity of I Declare War's premise - presenting an afterschool game of war in a way that looks and feels as real to viewers as it does to the youngsters in the thick of it - to be matched by the cunning of its execution
Morales's often brutal morality tale has both a grim intensity and a shattering impact.

For all of its flash, the movie aims for the utmost sincerity as a grand love story. Alas, Luhrmann doesn't quite have Fitzgerald's finesse when it comes to handling the shift between gilt-edged satire and heart-rending pathos.
Cuarón is so successful at immersing viewers in the astronauts' environment that Gravity is only marginally hampered by its flaws.
The propaganda films produced by both sides in the '30s and '40s might've been objectionable for many reasons but at least they had the good sense to show real planes in action.

Though the subject matter inevitably seems a little sexed-up and contrived compared to recent docs like How to Survive a Plague, director Jean-Marc Vallée rarely wastes an ounce of Matthew McConaughey's gusto.
This is hardly the reassuring, audience-friendly coming-of-age-and-out tale it could've been. It's very much a two-hander between opponents who are equally matched and often equally flawed.

The personalities of the players also contribute energy. They are an immensely charismatic bunch.

movie_review_blurb: Hard to beat that title, ain't it?
Run Robot Run! should reassure viewers that they need not fear the new mechanical beings who will soon be part of their lives. They're better off watching out for the co-workers they have right now.

More surprising is how lushly romantic the film seems now -- even the frostiest qualities of the director's volatile aesthetic are warmed by the Riviera sunlight and the presence of Karina at her most beguiling.

movie_review_blurb: The vitality Vitti displays makes her absence deeply felt in the film's infamously ambiguous final scenes.

The most depressing thing of all is that Michael will likely survive even this dire endeavour.
Vitus's cool intelligence, knotty narrative and precise performances make it a pleasure to watch even when it sends mixed messages about the true nature of its protagonist.

The script's wry humour and Kwan's sure touch with her cast save it from becoming too sombre or too sentimental. In fact, she's created something rare: a family movie that makes keen observations about family life.

Isabella Rossellini's second collaboration with Guy Maddin is a delightfully odd tribute to her director father Roberto.

The geographical shift from Tsai's familiar Taipei to his homeland of Malaysia results in both a revitalization of those elements and a new level of visual beauty. The stunning final shot makes it a masterpiece.
movie_title: I Don't Want to Sleep Alone (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It's impossible not to think of the many other 'green-card soldiers' -- desperate Latin Americans offered breaks on permanent resident status in exchange for military enlistment -- who've paid the highest price for a shot at a better life.
movie_title: The Short Life of Jose Antonio Gutierrez (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The film's slow, sublime vistas elicit questions about our relationship with the natural world, which is never as straightforward as we might hope.

Director Martin Weisz does an adequate job of maintaining the movie's tension and momentum, but the lack of compelling characters and the unusual level of nastiness makes this an arduous mission for all involved.
The trouble with Pride is that it sticks so close to the sports-movie playbook that it never comes alive.

Boy Culture is an undemanding but sufficiently engaging serving of smut and sentiment. As such, it reclaims territory that queer cinema has largely ceded to TV shows like Queer as Folk, The L Word and Six Feet Under.
The movie's uninteresting characters, boneheaded dialogue and flagrantly nonsensical narrative detract considerably from the virtues of the visual design.
Sunflower succeeds as both a moving family drama and a microcosm of China's social history since the 1970s.
Best-in-show citations go to shorts by Manoel De Oliveira and David Cronenberg.
movie_title: Chacun son cinéma (To Each His Cinema) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Puerile and idiotic it may be, but Superhero Movie is nonetheless smarter than most of its lowbrow brethren in the Hollywood sub-sub-category known as the spoof movie.
While Bassett's performance deserves a better forum than Perry can provide, she gives his latest movie a sense of dignity its predecessors lacked.
Thoughtfully crafted but ultimately lugubrious, Green's latest only really connects when the director sticks to the small stuff.

Engrossing and often harrowing.
Doesn't measure up.

Lawrence [has] rarely been more appealing. That's partly because this latest incarnation of his usual persona is more vulnerable and likeable, but mostly it's a relief not to see him strain so hard to Bogart all the jokes.

The third in the modestly successful franchise spawned by the ultraviolent video-game, Resident Evil: Extinction provides little in the way of satisfying explanations or, for that matter, satisfying anything.

Give this call a miss.
The details just get stranger and stranger.

A bland, timid and thoroughly un-thrilling teen thriller.

t's a thoughtful, bracing drama in the mould of Lawrence's much-decorated Lantana.

movie_review_blurb: A richly textured variation on The Postman Always Rings Twice.
movie_title: Story of a Love Affair (Cronaca di un amore) (1950)

movie_review_blurb: Zoom is a movie that you've probably seen several times already.

Wise, resonant and genuinely special.
